column5: For each of the selected answers in Q1, please describe what responsibilities they have for LGBTQ+ DE&I in your organisation.
column6: Our Board is ultimately responsible for driving L&G's D&I agenda which includes embracing and progressing the LGBTQ+ agenda, and we have a dedicated Independent Non-Executive Director, Nilufer Von Bismarck OBE, who is the Designated Workforce Director responsible for engaging with employees and representing their views. Part of our Board's responsibilities are to hold our Group D&I Council to account for defining and implementing our global D&I strategy. Our Group D&I Council is chaired by Laura Mason, CEO, Private Markets and a member of our Group Management Committee. For us D&I goes beyond the traditional focus on “protected characteristics” such as age, ethnicity, sexual orientation, disability and gender identity. While these are very important indicators of what an individual’s perspective might be, we also think that every individual has unique circumstances and our Group D&I Council is accountable for understanding our employees perspectives as well as shaping our D&I agenda. To drive the delivery of our D&I agenda, our Group Head of Inclusion, Group Inclusion Partners and HR teams (Talent Acquisition, Engagement, Policy, Learning ﹠ Development) each play a part in implementing L&G's strategy. Each of our divisional CEOs (and members of our Group Executive Committee) have a proportion of their bonus awarded based on culture. Our annual "Culture Review" process is an in-depth assessment of the levels of inclusion across our business, where we look at diversity data, employee feedback and progress made against our stated D&I goals. Lastly, we have an active and engaged global employee network specifically for LGBTQ+ people and allies - Our "L&GBT+Allies" network. This network champions the voice and experience of LGBTQ+ colleagues, reaches out to community and society and drives our inclusive agenda forwards.
column8:
Certainly! Here's a summary of the responsibilities related to LGBTQ+ DE&I within your organisation based on the provided response:

1. **Board of Directors**  
   - Ultimate accountability for driving L&G's Diversity & Inclusion (D&I) agenda, inclusive of LGBTQ+ matters.  
   - Hold the Group D&I Council accountable for defining and implementing the global D&I strategy.  
   - Designated Workforce Director (Independent Non-Executive Director, Nilufer Von Bismarck OBE) engages with employees, representing their views, including those related to LGBTQ+ inclusion.

2. **Group D&I Council**  
   - Chairs by Laura Mason, CEO of Private Markets.  
   - Accountable for understanding employee perspectives, including LGBTQ+ experiences and needs.

3. **Group Head of Inclusion, Group Inclusion Partners, and HR Teams**

4. **Divisional CEOs and Group Executive Committee Members**

5. **Culture Review Process**  
   - An annual, in-depth assessment of inclusion levels across the business.

column11: For each of the selected stakeholder groups in Q3, please describe who they are and how they are measured against LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objectives. Please confirm that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column12: Our Board is ultimately accountable for ensuring L&G is a diverse and inclusive place. On an annual basis, the Board publishes progress against our Group Diversity Policy which covers our commitments on D&I. On a quarterly basis the Board, via our Nominations & Corporate Governance Committee, receives progress updates from our Group D&I Council on issues and progress. - Our Group Executive Committee (C-Suite and Executive Management) are responsible for delivering against our internal and external D&I commitments. Our Group Execs each have 10% of their variable bonus attributed to their performance creating an inclusive culture. Our annual Culture Review process is undertaken as a bottom-up and top-down review of progress around culture, including on our aims to create a diverse workforce and inclusive workplace. - Our group and divisional D&I teams are targeted to deliver against their respective D&I plans as part of our regular performance review process. - As well as the regular performance review process, Line Managers are also assessed using colleague feedback from their teams. The data is captured using our "Voice" employee surveys (every 6months). We ask colleagues to provide feedback against a number of issues including inclusion, connection / belonging, speaking out and purposeful leadership. It's also worth acknowledging our view on targets. We want to see regular, progressive improvements in the diversity of our workforce. We won’t be setting outcome targets; instead we track progress against a baselines. This is for a number of reasons: - we recognise that our work to increase the diversity of our workforce and the inclusion of our workplace will never be done - it's a journey of continuous improvement. - It’s also because we have a diverse business. Hove, Cardiff, Chicago, Hong Kong, Singapore and London are very different places, and success will look slightly different for every business we run and every geography we operate in. - We also know that data about our employees is critical if we’re to understand the progress we’re making against our vision: we’ll only know how successful we’ve been when we understand the scale of the challenge we face. - What doesn’t change is our overall vision of a diverse workforce and an inclusive workplace. Our group-wide ambition is to deliver progressive improvement against a range of trackable data.
column14:
The selected stakeholder groups referenced are:

1. **The Board**  
   - **Who they are:** The company’s Board of Directors, ultimately accountable for ensuring that the organization is diverse and inclusive.  
   - **Measurement:** They publish an annual progress report against the Group Diversity Policy, which includes D&I commitments. Quarterly updates are provided via the Nominations & Corporate Governance Committee based on reports from the Group D&I Council.  

2. **Group Executive Committee (C-Suite and Executive Management)**  
   - **Who they are:** The top executives responsible for delivering on internal and external D&I commitments.  
   - **Measurement:** 10% of their variable bonus is tied to performance in creating an inclusive culture. Their contribution is also assessed through an annual Culture Review that evaluates progress in developing a diverse workforce and inclusive workplace.

3. **Group and Divisional D&I Teams**  
   - **Who they are:** Dedicated Diversity & Inclusion teams at the group and divisional levels responsible for executing D&I plans.  
   - **Measurement:** Performance is reviewed regularly in alignment with their D&I plans as part of the standard performance review process.

4. **Line Managers**  
   - **Who they are:** Supervisors responsible for managing teams and fostering an inclusive work environment.  
   - **Measurement:** Assessed via colleague feedback collected through the "Voice" employee surveys conducted every six months. Feedback covers inclusion, connection/belonging, speaking out, and purposeful leadership.

column17: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column18: We amplify voices of our LGBT+ employees and their allies not just around Pride but throughout the year on our internal communication channels (the Hub) and regular updates from senior leaders. For example, in 2024 we asked we asked a number of our LGBT+ colleagues to share their personal journeys and the collective significance of Pride month on our Intranet. We promote the events organised by our L&GBT+Allies Network across the group with the support of senior execs and have taken steps in 2024 to focus on the Allyship aspects of the network (e.g. our Allyship Unmasked: Inspiring Stories of Support event in May 2024 held in conjunction with LGBT Great and chaired by Michael Marks, the network’s senior sponsor). Other networks are also keen to partner up with L&GBT in organising family/parenting events (Family and Carers Network) and LGBT+ mental health events (Health&Wellbeing) and also recognise the challenges faced by LGBT+ individuals across the world (Culture Club). All employees have a Culture/D﹠I objective which is measured as part of the annual review process, additionally colleagues who support the LGBT agenda are recognised through the Chairman's awards, opportunities to attend LGBT+ awards, partake in mentoring and leadership development, educational and social events organised by the LGBT committee and funded by the business.
column20:
Your organisation recognises and rewards employees supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I efforts through multiple initiatives:

- Amplifying the voices of LGBT+ employees and allies throughout the year via internal communication channels (the Hub) and updates from senior leaders.
- Featuring personal journeys and stories from LGBT+ colleagues, such as those shared on your Intranet during Pride month 2024.
- Promoting events organised by the LGBT+ Allies Network with senior executive support, including targeted allyship activities like the "Allyship Unmasked: Inspiring Stories of Support" event in May 2024, held in partnership with LGBT Great and chaired by the network’s senior sponsor, Michael Marks.
- Collaborations between LGBT+ Network and other employee networks (e.g., Family and Carers Network, Health & Wellbeing, Culture Club) to organise intersectional events addressing family, mental health, and global LGBT+ challenges.
- Incorporating Culture/D&I objectives in all employees’ annual reviews.
- Recognition via the Chairman’s awards for colleagues supporting the LGBT agenda.
- Providing opportunities to attend LGBT+ awards, participate in mentoring and leadership development, and engage in educational and social events organised by the LGBT committee, all funded by the business.

These measures collectively show a structured and ongoing commitment to recognising and rewarding employees’ contributions to LGBTQ+ DE&I.

column35: For each of the selected options in Q3, please describe how your LGBTQ+ DE&I strategy addresses each option.
column36: Workforce planning, succession planning & promotion HR and business colleagues have access to our workforce data and use it as part of our Strategic Workforce Planning processes. HR have access to the data to identify and resolve issues around promotion. LGBTQ+ Talent Attraction/Recruitment Recruitment is a key lever for our Group-wide D&I strategy. Our Talent Acquisition teams work closely with external partners to attract diverse candidates for all roles including work experience and internships. We've also adopted a policy of blind CVs to reduce the risk of bias in our shortlisting and selection processes. Talent Retention In terms of Talent Retention and Learning & Development, we recognise our role as an inclusive employer is about creating opportunities for people to develop and acquire skills. We also recognise that the quality of Line Management across L&G is a key lever for us to improve productivity, inclusion and engagement. We're committed to offering all 1900 of our Line Managers the chance to improve knowledge and skills. Coupled with this programme is a range of focused learning interventions on topics such as inclusive leadership and inclusive management, better decisions, building diverse teams and inclusive ways of working. Learning & Development The L&GBT+ Network has a workstream dedicated to Learning & Development, which focuses on organising events and creating resources and programmes providing education on LGBTQ+ topics. In 2024 this workstream organised a several educational events utilising our relationships with our charity partners, added a number of educational resources to our network hub which can be accessed across the business, and launched a company wide Allyship training programme. Pay, rewards & benefits Staff are rewarded based on their end of year appraisal, objectives are linked to DEI, In addition colleagues championing LGBT+ diversity have received tickets to LGBT awards, enjoy company sponsored social networking and LGBT+ events together with Career development and mentoring opportunities. DE&I Data Capture / Analysis / KPIs At the heart of our Group-wide D&I approach is the data we ask our people to share. LGBT+ status and gender identity are two key pieces of data we ask employees to share. This data, along with a range of other "protected characteristics" is reported and tracked using our Group-wide D&I Dashboards. These dashboards allow us to track representation across the employee lifecycle - attraction, hiring / new joiners, promotions and leavers. We use this data in a number of ways: - our Group D&I Council reviews this data quarterly and invites our Divisional / Functional leadership teams to explain trends in their data - leadership teams receive the data monthly as part of their standard reporting - our Nominations Committee and Board will review extracts of the data on an annual basis to ensure we are delivering against our goals Communications Visibility is an important part of LGBTQ+ inclusion. Employee stories and testimonials from LGBTQ+ colleagues are shared both through internal L&G News communications and externally through a variety of channels including our website and LinkedIn. Procurement The procurement policy explicitly calls out discrimination on the basis of sexuality and or gender identity.

column46: The following policies cover those ticked above and apply to all UK employees of companies in the Legal & General Group which are wholly owned by Legal & General and the policy attachments relate specifically to these. Diversity and inclusion policy: covers sexual orientation, gender identity and expression and trans (which includes transgender, non-binary and gender non-conforming) employees Dignity at work policy: covers bullying, harrassment and stalking to create a work environment free from harassment and bullying, where everyone is treated with dignity and respect – whatever their sexual orientation, gender identity and gender expression Family leave policy: this includes adoption, maternity, paternity and shared parental leave and is available regardless of sexual orientation, gender identity and gender expression Trans and non-binary policy: this is specifically aimed to recognise, support and understand an employees gender identity and gender expression. It includes a guide for trans employees and also one for colleagues of trans employees. We have a manager guide that is separate to the policy, to help them support a trans employee.
column48:
Certainly! Here is a summary of each selected policy along with supporting commentary. Please note that the attached policy documents pertain specifically to UK employees within the Legal & General Group companies wholly owned by Legal & General.

1. Diversity and Inclusion Policy  
- **Overview:** This policy promotes an inclusive workplace respecting all protected characteristics, including sexual orientation, gender identity, and gender expression. It explicitly covers transgender, non-binary, and gender non-conforming employees.  
- **Supporting Commentary:** The policy ensures that all employees feel valued and respected regardless of their identity, fostering an environment where diversity of thought and background is embraced as a business and ethical imperative.

2. Dignity at Work Policy  
- **Overview:** This policy aims to create a workplace free from bullying, harassment, and stalking. It strictly prohibits such behaviours and promotes treating everyone with dignity and respect, explicitly including protections based on sexual orientation, gender identity, and gender expression.  
- **Supporting Commentary:** By safeguarding employees against harassment and bullying, the policy underpins a safe and supportive working environment conducive to productivity and wellbeing.

3. Family Leave Policy  
- **Overview:** This policy covers adoption, maternity, paternity, and shared parental leave. Importantly, these leave entitlements are accessible regardless of an employee's sexual orientation, gender identity, or gender expression.  
- **Supporting Commentary:** The inclusive approach to family leave demonstrates the company’s commitment to supporting all types of families and caregiving arrangements, promoting equality and work-life

column61: How does your organisation utilise sexual orientation and gender identity diversity data to improve LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column62: The way we use sexual orientation and gender identity data to improve outcomes for LGBTQ+ people as well as support our wider DEI agenda, is ever evolving. - We have enacted improvements on how we collect DEI data removing the transgender option from gender identity question as this is not appropriate and instead have included the question asking "Is your current gender the same as the one identified at birth?" . The aim of this is to be more inclusive for our trans+ colleagues. - We continue to use this data throughout the employee lifecycle from attraction and hiring, through employee onboarding and then key milestones in an employee’s life with us at L&G. This may include promotion, mobility and when they ultimately choose to leave the firm. Having data at these stages in the employees journey delivers value for the firm because it allows us to identify hidden dynamics that may exist and may advantage / disadvantage certain groups. We don’t report these externally although we use the insight to shape our D&I work. For employees it gives comfort that we’re working hard to make L&G an open, inclusive employer.
column65: What campaigns, strategies or approaches has your organisation undertaken to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data?
column66: For new joiners we have prompts within their onboarding journey to ensure their information is accurate. They are also auto enrolled into the Hive Intro to Inclusion learning. We have an annual Count Me In campaign where communications go out across the business to encourage employees to share this data with the business and we have recently made changes to the options within our HRMS to better reflect how gender identity is disclosed.
column68:
Your organisation has implemented several campaigns, strategies, and approaches to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data:

1. **Onboarding Prompts:** New joiners receive prompts during their onboarding journey to ensure their self-ID information is accurate and up-to-date.

2. **Intro to Inclusion Learning:** New employees are auto-enrolled into the Hive Intro to Inclusion learning program, which likely helps build awareness and comfort around DE&I topics.

3. **Annual Count Me In Campaign:** This campaign involves communications sent across the business to encourage employees to share their self-ID DE&I data voluntarily.

4. **HRMS Updates:** Recently, the options within your Human Resource Management System (HRMS) have been updated to better reflect how gender identity is disclosed, making it more inclusive and comfortable for employees to share such information.

Together, these efforts aim to create a supportive environment that normalizes self-ID disclosure and ensures accuracy and inclusivity in DE&I data collection.
column71: How does your organisation target and attract LGBTQ+ talent?
column72: L&G careers website: Our new careers website includes employee testimonials and story telling from our colleagues, including those from the LGBT+ community. Our over-arching statement about diversity and inclusion is: 'At L&G, we stand for inclusion. Get this right, and our culture will speak to a future where we’re known for being fair, transparent, customer-led, and economically and socially useful. A workplace where differences breed originality, and you can be at your best no matter who you are'. The language on our careers site is deliberately focused on how we aim to empower people to be at their best no matter who they are which is all encompassing. This is also reflected in the imagery we use, for example in our 'Diversity and Inclusion at Legal & General' video, which includes video footage of members of our LGBT+ community. Diversity and Inclusion at L&G video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=djTs2V4JUFs L&G Life webpage on the our careers site: https://www.legalandgeneral.com/careers/legal-and-general-life Example LGBT+ employee testimonials: https://www.linkedin.com/posts/legal-%26-general_pridemonth-pride-lgbt-activity-7211279397897601024-fC4r https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/pride-month-like-other-andrzej-pioch-cfa/ https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/active-allyship-using-my-privilege-bring-people-together-ahuja/ Statement from our CEO: https://www.linkedin.com/posts/ant%C3%B3nio-sim%C3%B5es_onwardsandupwards-pridemonth-legalandgeneral-activity-7212397274390278144-dpKm?utm_source=li_share&utm_content=feedcontent&utm_medium=g_dt_web&utm_campaign=copy
column74:
Our organisation targets and attracts LGBTQ+ talent through a comprehensive approach focused on inclusion and representation:

1. Careers Website:
   - We feature employee testimonials and storytelling from colleagues across the LGBT+ community, providing authentic voices and experiences.
   - Our overarching diversity and inclusion statement emphasizes a culture where everyone can be their best regardless of identity:  
     “At L&G, we stand for inclusion. Get this right, and our culture will speak to a future where we’re known for being fair, transparent, customer-led, and economically and socially useful. A workplace where differences breed originality, and you can be at your best no matter who you are.”
   - The language on our site is deliberately empowering and all-encompassing.
   - Visuals and videos, such as the ‘Diversity and Inclusion at Legal & General’ video, prominently include members of our LGBT+ community, reinforcing our commitment visually.

2. Videos and Online Content:
   - The "Diversity and Inclusion at L&G" video showcases real members of our LGBT+ community and underscores our inclusive culture.
   - We provide ongoing LGBT+ employee testimonials on platforms like LinkedIn, sharing personal experiences and highlighting active allyship.

3. Leadership Support:

column89: Please describe and attach examples of the content covered by this training.
column90: The LGBT allyship training offers practical advice and strategies on how employees can actively support their LGBT+ colleagues and create a welcoming environment for all. The training also delves into the meaning and history of Pride, exploring its origins, significance, and evolution over the years. This section provides context on why Pride is celebrated and its ongoing importance in promoting equality and visibility for the LGBT+ community. Additionally, the training keeps employees informed about current news and events related to Pride, ensuring everyone is aware of important developments and initiatives. Finally, it introduces our company's LGBT network, outlining the resources, groups, and support systems available to employees. This network serves as a valuable tool for fostering connection and creating a sense of community within the workplace. In addition to the resources attached we have hosted and made available to L&G employees in-person and virtual events, hosted with partners such as LGBT Great and Interinvest. In June we hosted the Allyship Unmasked event, this inspiring event brought a captivating journey into the heart of allyship, where industry heroes shared their transformative stories of support and solidarity. The event was a collaborative effort with LGBT Great, and we welcomed peers from various financial services companies to convene at our Coleman Street premises for an engaging panel discussion. In August we celebrated South Asian Heritage Month, and held an event with the theme 'Free to Be Me' in collaboration with Interinvest. We were delighted to welcome Laks Mann MBE from the South Asian Heritage Month team. He illustrated how FreeToBeMe enables us to celebrate our backgrounds and the dynamic nature of identity in different contexts and intersectionality. In September we hosted the InterInvest Bi+ Awareness Week panel, in partnership with Just Like Us! The panel was an insightful conversation with Ambassadors from Just Like Us, who will shed light on how the next generation increasingly views sexuality as fluid and on the expectations around bi+** inclusion in the workplace and LGBTQ+ spaces.

column94: We hold ourselves and our employees to high standards when it comes to role modelling responsible behaviour as it’s important to us that all our stakeholders can expect us to behave fairly and to do the right thing. We have a number of a Group-wide policies that highlight our commitment to ethical and responsible behaviour, which you can find below. Legal & General are acutely aware of how our business impacts on society and the environment. We are proud of being a company that does business responsibly and ethically. We strive to work with like-minded businesses and use our supplier governance processes to promote socially responsible behaviour across the supply chain. Legal & General require our suppliers to comply with our Supplier Code of Conduct at all times and be able to demonstrate compliance. The purpose of our Supplier Code of Conduct is to clarify and safeguard the relationships between us and our suppliers, to establish standards that ensure our suppliers operate ethically, are environmentally responsible and that workers are treated with respect and dignity. Our suppliers must have processes in place to maintain these standards and be able to provide evidence if required. These processes are scrutinised closely both as part of the procurement process but also as part of the ongoing commercial arrangement. This code of conduct is reviewed and recertified on an annual basis to ensure that are supplier remains compliant with the policy. For key suppliers, Legal & General hold formal quarterly and annual strategic reviews where performance, opportunities and strategic alignment are reviewed. We have published an organisation-wide agenda to make discussions on topics, such as sustainability and corporate social responsibility, a standard practice of working with suppliers. This includes areas such as employee welfare, the living wage as well as diversity and inclusion within the supplier’s business. We encourage collaboration between organisations on issues such as LGBTQ+ and have held joint meetings between employee resource groups to drive progress on shared objectives. Since 2021 we have been a member of the Social Enterprise UK. which is the biggest network of social enterprises in the UK. This membership allows for us to search and engage with suppliers for various products and services within the Social Enterprise UK community.

column114: Within Legal & General there are a number of policies to foster an inclusive environment and the HR department in particular have liaised with the L&GBT+Allies Network to ensure that the policies reflect considerations within the LGBT+ community and this is illustrated in the following: • The Diversity and Inclusion policy – to ensure that no job applicant, fellow employee or worker, customer or supplier is discriminated against on the grounds of: Age, Religion or belief, Creed, Colour, Disability, Gender or gender identity, Gender reassignment, Marital status or civil partnership status, Nationality, National origin, Parental carer status, Pregnancy, childbirth, maternity or paternity, Race or ethnic origin, Sexual orientation, Transgender, Union membership, Reduced hours working • The Dignity at Work policy – this states that L&G care about the people we work with and for, which is why we’re committed to creating a work environment free from harassment and bullying where everyone is treated with dignity and respect regardless of their sexual orientation, gender identity and gender expression • The Adoption, Maternity, Paternity and Shared parental leave policies all state that benefits apply regardless of gender • Trans and Non-binary policy which ensures that L&G provide support to any employee who is intending to change their name and gender in the workplace and to make sure that the systems are updated to reflect this. It also shows a clear commitment to supporting all trans people, including those with non-binary identities with information on language and terminology and guidance on facilities and dress code • Healthcare Insurance – The current L&G policy is open to all employees and their partners regardless of their gender and gender identity, and dependents. The policy provides a maximum of £10,000 for trans individuals to enable pre-operative support in the form of Cognitive Behaviour Therapy and Psychotherapy. All our policies were reviewed and signed off by our ERGs, the union and Stonewall. The trans and non binary policies were signed off by Stonewall and the Global Butterflies. We also ensure that all our comms (internal and external) are inclusive
column117: If yes, please list the organisations.
column118: The Summers Work Experience programme, which we have been able to continue since 2019, provides young people from schools, colleges and several social enterprises (including Investment20/20) who have no work experience opportunities with two weekly programmes. The aim is to equip these individuals with invaluable insight into aspects of the corporate world, such as the diversity of roles and entry formats available to them, as well as assisting them in selecting a career path, building their confidence, learning new skills and facilitating professional networking opportunities. We also continue to host two ‘Meet the Stemettes’ events - a panel of female employees answered questions from an audience of 9 to 13 year olds and gave advice on work experience, GCSE options and also questions about their jobs. Similarly, we regularly host student insight days with industry professionals from a varied range of backgrounds and business areas presented and offered top career tips to students. LGIM is supporting the #10000Blackinterns initiative aimed at encouraging young black talented individuals to consider a career in asset management. LGIM is working hard alongside our peers to make our industry more accessible and to ensure everyone has the same opportunity to succeed. We have also partnered with Girlguiding, the UK’s largest charity for girls and young women, to support and sponsor their new Saver badge. This is an initiative aimed at encouraging guides to develop their understanding of money, making finances accessible and easy to understand. This is particularly important as 53% of women between 17 and 21 say that having to pay university fees is one of their biggest fears of the future. Finally, we have been involved in several high profile initiatives through Diversity Project, Investment 2020, Fast Futures, 30% Club, LGBT Great, #talkaboutblack including the #IAM campaign, the Vision Foundation, Moving Ahead and Investing in Ethnicity, Employers Network for Equality & Inclusion (ENEI), Business in the Community / BITC Cymru, Women in Finance Charter, Race at Work Charter, Out in Finance (an LGBTQ+ industry initiative in Chicago) to raise awareness of the importance of LGBT+ inclusion in the workplace.

column8:
The responsibilities for LGBTQ+ Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DE&I) within the organisation are distributed among several key roles and groups:

1. **LGBTQ+ Affinity Group**: This group drives LGBTQ+ activities and initiatives across the Vanquis Banking Group, serving as the primary force behind LGBTQ+ DE&I efforts.

2. **Chief Executive Officer (Overall Inclusion Sponsor)**: The CEO provides high-level leadership and sponsorship for LGBTQ+ inclusion, underscoring its importance within the organisation’s strategic priorities.

3. **Executive Sponsor (Director of CEO Office and Group ExCo Member)**: This executive offers active support and representation at the executive committee level, helping to align DE&I initiatives with organisational goals.

4. **Affinity Group Chair (I&D Manager)**: The Inclusion & Diversity manager leads the affinity group, coordinating efforts, managing activities, and ensuring effective communication and implementation of LGBTQ+ DE&I strategies.

5. **Members of the People Function (Including Comms Team)**: These individuals support the affinity group by managing communications, employee engagement, and integration of DE&I initiatives into HR and organisational practices.

6. **Wider Staff Members**: Employees from various parts of the organisation participate in the affinity group, contributing diverse perspectives and helping to foster an inclusive culture throughout the company.

Together, these roles collaborate to promote LGBTQ+ inclusion, influence policies, organize events, and ensure that LGBTQ+ DE&I remains an integral part of the organisation’s culture and operations.

column65: What campaigns, strategies or approaches has your organisation undertaken to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data?
column66: We have an intranet page fully explaining how colleagues sharing their data with us. Five reasons to share your diversity data 1 It will make a significant positive difference To understand and best support our diverse population, we need accurate data. Without it, how can we be sure we're making the right decisions and focusing on the areas that will make the biggest difference? 2 It’s secure Much like your bank details and salary, your personal information is completely secure. In fact, it’s only visible to you and a handful of colleagues with super-user access. Your data is stored and managed following strict GDPR guidelines and will never be used for any other purpose. 3 It’s not just about you We need to think big picture. The data you choose to share will give us a clearer view of the many facets of who we all are and will be used to inform decisions at a wider level. The more data we have, the clearer the view. Plus, accurate data allows us track, evidence and celebrate whenever we make meaningful positive changes. 4 It’s easy It’s just a case of answering a few questions. It only takes a minute and you can update your responses at any time. Just log in to your local HR portal and select the Diversity Form. 5 It’s optional, but… We all have a role to play in improving inclusion and diversity across the Group, so a response from every colleague would be ideal. You can respond ‘prefer not to answer’ to any of the questions, which is a perfectly valid response. Even if you feel you're fully represented, adding your data will help because more responses mean more accurate stats. column68:
Your organisation has implemented a comprehensive approach to encourage comfort and participation in disclosing self-identified Diversity, Equity & Inclusion (DE&I) data by:

1. Creating an informative intranet page that clearly explains the importance and benefits of sharing diversity data.
2. Providing five key reasons why employees should share their data:
   - **Making a significant positive difference:** Highlighting how accurate data enables better decision-making and targeted support for the diverse workforce.
   - **Assuring data security:** Emphasising that personal information is securely stored, visible only to the individual and a limited number of authorised personnel, and managed in compliance with GDPR.
   - **Promoting collective impact:** Illustrating that shared data benefits the entire organisation by informing broader inclusion efforts and helping celebrate successes.
   - **Ensuring ease of sharing:** Making the process quick and simple via a few questions accessible through the HR portal, with the ability to update responses anytime.
   - **Respecting voluntariness while encouraging participation:** Acknowledging that sharing is optional, with choices to select ‘prefer not to answer’, but encouraging full participation to improve data accuracy.
3. Providing additional resources such as Data Collection FAQs to address concerns about data handling and privacy.

This multi-faceted strategy focuses on transparency, trust-building, ease of use, and fostering a sense of collective responsibility to improve comfort around self-ID DE&I data disclosure.

column6: We have the following governance structure to support LGBT+ inclusion at our organization. The DEI Committee is comprised of representatives from the Executive Committee, Senior Management and Human Resources. The Committee sets the firm overall DEI strategy, monitors progress and allocates budgetary resources. We also have a dedicated regional council. The council is responsible for implementing our strategy at the regional level. Our ERGs lead on championing grass-roots efforts led by employees and support our overall diversity, equity and inclusion goals. DEI Regional Council The Regional Councils are comprised of regional employees who identify aspects of diversity and inclusion relevant and important in their region. They collaborate with the DEI Committee and Employee Resource Groups to implement strategy at a local level. We have three regional councils EMEA, Asia Pacific and North America that support our DEI Strategy. Employee Resource Groups The Employee Resource Groups (ERG) are grassroots, employee-led effort that offer colleagues with common interests an opportunity to meet on a regular basis and discuss how they can make Janus Henderson a more inclusive workplace for all.

column17: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column18: As part of our ongoing commitment to fostering an inclusive workplace, we are pleased to announce several key initiatives designed to recognise and support our Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) efforts across the organization. These initiatives aim to celebrate our achievements, reinforce our culture-building goals, and ensure the continuous development of our employees and leaders in DEI-related activities. 1. DEI Awards Program Launch: This year marks the introduction of our DEI Awards, a significant initiative to acknowledge the exceptional contributions of our Employee Resource Groups (ERGs) and individual members who have played a pivotal role in driving specific campaigns, such as LGBTQ+ History Month. This program enables both our CEO and the organization to honour outstanding efforts in advancing our DEI objectives. 2. Integration of ERG Goals in Year-End Reviews: We are requesting ERG Leaders to incorporate their specific DEI targets into their Performance Reviews (PR). This inclusion will ensure that managers consider the achievements in culture-building and DEI objectives as integral components of the overall employee evaluation process. 3. HR Communications to Managers: To reinforce our DEI commitments, HR will periodically issue reminders to managers. These communications are designed to encourage managers to actively support ERG Leads within their teams by promoting their projects and fostering an environment of active allyship across the broader organization. 4. Executive Sponsor Recognition: To further acknowledge the efforts of our ERG Leads, Executive Sponsors will send personalised emails to line managers. These communications will highlight the importance of recognising ERG Lead contributions and ensuring they receive the necessary support to bring our firm’s values to life. 5. LGBT Great Initiative Participation: We continue to nominate employees for external recognition through the LGBT Great initiative, celebrating LGBT+ role models and allies within our firm. Selected individuals will be spotlighted on our social media channels, and we will sponsor their participation in conferences and training sessions to further their development.
column20:
Your organisation recognises and rewards employees supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I efforts through a multi-faceted approach:

1. **DEI Awards Program:** A new initiative to acknowledge exceptional contributions by Employee Resource Groups (ERGs) and individuals involved in campaigns like LGBTQ+ History Month. These awards are presented by the CEO and the organisation to highlight outstanding DEI efforts.

2. **Incorporating ERG Goals in Performance Reviews:** ERG leaders include DEI-related targets in their year-end performance reviews, ensuring their culture-building and DEI accomplishments are formally evaluated and recognised by managers.

3. **HR Communications to Managers:** HR regularly reminds managers to support ERG leads within their teams by promoting their projects and encouraging active allyship, fostering an inclusive workplace culture.

4. **Executive Sponsor Recognition:** Executive Sponsors send personalised emails to line managers to emphasise the importance of recognising and supporting ERG leads, reinforcing the company’s commitment to living its values.

5. **Participation in LGBT Great Initiative:** Employees are nominated for external recognition as part of the LGBT Great initiative to celebrate LGBT+ role models and allies. Recognised individuals gain visibility via social media and are sponsored for conference attendance and training to support their ongoing development.

These combined efforts ensure employees’ contributions to LGBTQ+ DE&I are visible, valued, and rewarded both internally and externally.

column24: We are excited to share several strategic initiatives that underscore our firm’s commitment to diversity, equity, inclusion (DE&I), and leadership development within our Employee Resource Groups (ERGs). These initiatives represent powerful actions taken to not only foster an inclusive workplace but also to empower our ERG leaders and members with the skills and opportunities they need to excel and drive meaningful change. Innovative Mentoring Programs: At the forefront of our efforts is the development of a comprehensive mentoring program, spearheaded by the Executive Sponsor of our Pride ERG. This program, which includes mentoring, reciprocal mentoring, and reverse mentoring elements, is designed to facilitate a rich exchange of ideas, experiences, and insights among employees. Leveraging resources from LGBT Great, this initiative aims to launch in 2025, setting a new benchmark for leadership development and inclusion within our firm. Elevated Internal Training and Coaching: Recognising the pivotal role of continuous learning, we have institutionalised bi-annual refresher training for our ERG Leads. This initiative is tailored to ensure that our leaders remain at the cutting edge of DE&I practices, leadership strategies, and the management of dynamic and effective ERGs. External Training and Leadership Development: To further our commitment to nurturing our leaders, we are placing our ERG Leads on esteemed talent programs designed to enhance their leadership capabilities. This external coaching and training initiative is aimed at equipping our leaders with the skills necessary to inspire, guide, and make an impactful difference both within and outside our organization. Access to LGBTQ+ Focused Conferences and Events: We are providing our ERGs with unparalleled access to leading LGBTQ+ focused conferences and events, such as D&I Leaders. This access is crucial for keeping our ERG skill sets supported, fostering innovation, and ensuring our initiatives reflect the latest in DE&I thought leadership. Executive Sponsorship and Network Opportunities: Our Pride ERG’s Executive Sponsor is actively connecting our ERGs with a broader network of ERG sponsors and allies. This initiative is designed to enhance visibility, foster collaborations, and unlock new opportunities for our ERG members to engage, learn, and grow. These initiatives represent our firm's proactive and strategic approach to DE&I and leadership development. By investing in our people, fostering an inclusive culture, and creating pathways for professional growth, we are not only enhancing the employee experience but also driving forward our mission to be a leader in DE&I.

column46: Discrimination based on sexual orientation policy - diversity policy attached Discrimination based on gender identity and expression policy - diversity policy attached Transitioning at work (or equivalent) policy - policy screenshot attached. Wording: In line with our Inclusion & Diversity Policy, Beazley commits to recruit, retain and develop people with diverse backgrounds and experiences to thrive at all levels of our business, in a truly inclusive environment that operates zero tolerance to discrimination or harassment and fully supports and celebrates differences. This guide is for all managers and colleagues and is designed to provide support and information to assist anyone going through the transitioning process and once they have transitioned. ‘Trans’ is an overarching term to describe people whose gender is not the same as, or does not align comfortably with the sex they were assigned at birth. Transitioning involves the various steps a trans person may take to live in the gender with which they identify. Each person’s experience will be different. For some this involves medical intervention but not all trans people will have this. Transitioning may also involve changing pronouns, telling friends, family or colleagues, dressing differently or changing official documents and we understand that the levels of support an individual may require will vary. If an individual is considering transition, there are a number of things we can do at Beazley to support them. We encourage the individual to speak with their line manager and/or relevant C&P Business Partner in the first instance. Confidentiality Trans and non-binary colleagues will take the lead as to whether, when and how they wish to discuss their status. We understand some people may want to keep their gender identity private where others may wish to discuss either in confidence or more openly. We will respect the rights of the individual and great care will be taken not to do anything or share any information that breaches this confidentiality. Any information gathered by Beazley is held securely and only accessed by authorised colleagues with a legitimate need for the information. Absences from work We appreciate individuals may need to be away from work for medical appointments or surgical procedures as well as recovery time. The individual may also wish to work remotely for a period of time while undergoing any procedures. The individual should discuss any planned absences in advance with their line manager and/or relevant C&P Business Partner so the appropriate leave policies can be applied or adjustments made. We encourage the line manager and individual to remain in contact during any absences to agree any return to work plans or discuss any further adjustments that may be required. Communication The individual will confirm their details, the date effective and by what pronouns they wish to be addressed in the business moving forwards by discussing with their line manager and/or relevant C&P Business Partner. The C&P team will ensure records, directories, email accounts and so on are updated accordingly. The individual and their line manager should discuss how the individual wishes to communicate to others in the team or wider business of their name or pronoun change and agree how this should be done. Should the team or manager require more support, the C&P Business Partner or Inclusion Partner will be able to advise. It will be made clear that any transphobic or discriminatory comments will not be tolerated. Examples of this could be not respecting someone’s pronouns continued use of a trans person’s “deadname” (birth name or name they used prior to transitioning), being subjected to derogatory remarks about their gender identity, being “outed” or excluded as a result of their gender identity. Beazley operates a zero-tolerance policy towards any form of discrimination and any examples of transphobic bullying or harassment will be investigated fully. Facilities & Dress Code All colleagues are entitled to use the toilet or changing facilities appropriate to the gender in which they align with, regardless of whether they are currently undergoing or have undergone any gender reassignment. A number of Beazley offices have gender-neutral facilities which are available to use for all colleagues to use too. Beazley have a ‘dress for the day’ gender-neutral policy so individuals are empowered to use their own judgement on what to wear given their working day. If you have any questions about this document, the support available or would like to discuss further, either as someone considering or undergoing their transition or supporting another individual, please contact your C&P Business Partner Inclusive parental leave policy (i.e. shared maternity & parental leave) - policy screenshot attached. Inclusivity is at the heart of what we do, that’s why no matter how individuals come to parenthood, if they are a permanent employee they are entitled to 26 weeks fully paid leave as a day one right. Adoption leave policy - policy screenshot attached

column17: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column18: Employees are rewarded for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DEI in similar ways to other roles and projects they carry out in the firm – these are a combination of tangible and intangible rewards. Tangible rewards in the form of pay and bonuses are reviewed on an annual basis taking into account feedback from colleagues on each individual’s activities and performance over the year. Feedback on DEI work forms part of this process and can therefore influence reward. Intangible reward and recognition is provided through communications internally referring to named individuals who are leading on DEI projects, naming and recognition of Network members’ roles on internal SharePoint pages, and general visibility and recognition of each person’s contribution.
column19: Evidence of rewards and recognition infrastructure implemented for employees supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I initiatives.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dMon, 14 Oct 2024 15:41:21 GMT|
column20: Your organisation recognises and rewards employees supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I through both tangible and intangible means. Intangible recognition involves internal communications highlighting individuals leading DE&I projects, acknowledgment of Network members’ roles on internal platforms like SharePoint, and broader visibility of contributions within the organisation.
column23: For each of the selected responses in Q7, please describe what proactive actions have been taken in the last 12 months by individuals and the organisation.
column24: Internal/ external training: The firm provides training sessions, open to all employees, as part of the LGBT+ committee Pride month on an annual basis. This began in 2023 with a webinar from Global Butterflies followed by the LGBT Great Language Matters session in June 2024. These training sessions were facilitated by BW staff from the Pride Network and the sessions were led and presented by external trainers. The sessions have been recorded and made available and promoted to all staff, including leaders in the organisation, to view, although they were not specifically targeted at leadership. A separate training session was delivered by Kin&Co, external DEI consultants, to BW’s Management board in 2024, as part of the initial stage of a project led by Kin&Co to review and re-design BW’s overall strategy. Whilst this training was not specifically on LGBTQ+ issues, the LGBTQ+ perspective was covered as part of the DEI training. This project to review the DEI Strategy was pro-actively taken to Management Board by the DEI Steering Committee, led by Simon Rusling. Access to LGBTQ+ focussed conferences and events: External events are promoted and made available for all people in BW to attend, including leadership, although these have not been specifically targeted at the firm’s leadership. These events include O:pen and other industry LGBTQ+ focussed events which are mainly promoted via the Pride Network and the Network’s Viva Engage internal social platform. The firm’s management board also has updates and interaction with those involved in LGBTQ+ DEI work in other ways: DEI Steering Committee prepare a report for management board on a quarterly basis to update management board on the progress of DEI work. Andrew Vaughan, our Senior Partner, meets with our DEI Network leads (including the LGBTQ+ Network lead) every 6 months to connect and discuss ongoing DEI initiatives.

column65: What campaigns, strategies or approaches has your organisation undertaken to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data?
column66: Aligned HR and Network campaign launched in July 2024 to drive completion. Phase 1 activities included: - research into best practice and gained insight from other organisations - test group used to understand where and what barriers exist, to help inform campaign contents - each DEI network posts video to their community sharing the importance of data and how it can be used (variety of topics) - each Executive Sponsor of the DEI networks posts to their community sharing why it’s important to them to share their data - Targeted communications to Partners, Principals, “Vice Principals”, and Department Leaders to target low completion areas - Creation of resources to for audience to read more about key topics such as data security, how to input data, how it will be used - Visual displays in each office to encourage completion - Mentioned in key firmwide communications such as the Senior Partner’s Quarterly Briefings
column67: Evidence of a range of initiatives to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dWed, 16 Oct 2024 08:10:01 GMT|
column68:
Your organisation has implemented a comprehensive campaign and strategy aligned between HR and DEI networks, launched in July 2024, to improve comfort around disclosing self-identified DE&I data. Key approaches include:

- Conducting research into best practices and gaining insights from other organisations.
- Utilizing test groups to identify barriers to disclosure and inform campaign content.
- Having each DEI network share videos within their communities explaining the importance of the data and its uses.
- Engaging Executive Sponsors of DEI networks to post personal messages emphasizing why sharing data matters to them.
- Sending targeted communications to leadership roles (Partners, Principals, “Vice Principals,” Department Leaders) to address areas with low data completion.
- Creating accessible resources addressing key topics like data security, data input processes, and data usage.
- Setting up visual displays in each office to encourage participation.
- Including messages about data disclosure in significant firmwide communications, such as the Senior Partner’s Quarterly Briefings.

These combined efforts aim to build trust, transparency, and awareness to increase self-ID DE&I data completion.

column17: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column18: We run an employee recognition scheme, for which employees can be nominated for in light of their contributions in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I and Inclusion as a whole. During performance appraisals, all employees are reviewed on both business excellence and behaviour rating. For the purposes of behaviour rating, all managers have a cascaded goal of living up to our six manager expectations – one of which is being an enabler of inclusion and diversity. Evidence of their contribution may include, but not limited to, involvement in LGBT+ inclusion activity for which is considered as part of performance rating reviews.
column20: Your organisation recognises and rewards employees supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I through a formal employee recognition scheme where individuals can be nominated for their contributions. Additionally, during performance appraisals, employees are evaluated not only on business performance but also on behaviour, which includes adherence to key managerial expectations such as enabling inclusion and diversity. Contributions to LGBTQ+ inclusion activities are taken into account as evidence during these performance reviews, influencing behaviour ratings and overall performance assessments.

column93: If yes, please attach a copy of the policy and provide examples of how you hold your suppliers to account on LGBT+ DE&I.
column94: Yes, our organisation has a procurement policy to encourage LGBTQ+ DE&I with its suppliers. The Schroders procurement policy does not specifically reference LGBTQ+ DE&I, however we expect Schroders suppliers to follow the Supplier Code of Conduct which has a section about inclusion Inclusion, diversity and fair wages Schroders strives to create an inclusive culture that celebrates diversity. Our vision is for our people to reflect the diversity of the communities we live and work in. And for everyone to feel they truly belong at Schroders. Information about our approach can be found here. We believe in fair pay for performance, providing a good work environment that prioritises wellbeing, and providing personal growth opportunities. This helps us attract and retain exceptional employees. We are accredited living wage employers in both the United Kingdom (UK) and the United States of America (USA) and pay at least 10% above the minimum wage in all our locations globally. We expect our suppliers and their subcontractors to: - Abide by all relevant equality legislation in the countries in which they operate. - Be transparent, fair and consistent through any employment or hiring practices, ensuring there is no discrimination on the basis of age, sex or sexual orientation, gender identity, disability, origin, race, colour, religion or belief. - Embrace diversity, fairness and inclusion in their workforce/workplace, free from discrimination. - Comply with all applicable wage and working regulations and encourage suppliers to go beyond compliance with local minimum wages and, where applicable, pay a living wage to all direct employees and contractors. We also encourage our suppliers to support the adoption of the local living wage throughout its supply chain. - We will not tolerate harassment or discrimination in our working environment including that of our suppliers. When working at and for Schroders, if suppliers experience or witness any discriminatory actions or comments, we encourage these to be reported using the whistleblowing process detailed in section 6 below.

column148: Our dress code centres around dressing appropriately for your day. This means formal business attire if meeting clients or representing the company externally, business casual if in the office but not interacting with clients, and more casual again if you are working from home and not interacting with clients. Examples given of business casual are: – Smart casual trousers, including jeans and chinos – Smart casual skirts and dresses – Smart casual shirts with a collar including polo shirts – Smart casual footwear, including clean, well presented trainers However the above are not gendered- and any option would be considered appropriate for anyone- regardless of biological sex or gender identity. column18: DE&I is one of the three main pillars of the firm’s corporate sustainability strategy. column20:

Here’s a revised version of your response:

---

Our organisation recognises and rewards employees who actively support LGBTQ+ DE&I as part of our broader commitment to diversity, equity, inclusion, and sustainability. DE&I forms one of the three central pillars of our corporate sustainability strategy, with dedicated streams focusing on LGBTQ+, women, disabilities, and race.

Employees who contribute positively to LGBTQ+ inclusion—whether through advocacy, mentorship, participation in resource groups, or driving related initiatives—are acknowledged in our annual performance assessments with additive points. column71: How does your organisation target and attract LGBTQ+ talent?
column72: Diversity and Inclusion is embedded throughout our recruitment process. From making sure job descriptions and specifications are not unconsciously bias, to ensuring diverse interview panels and candidate pools, our specialist in-house recruitment team partner with the business end-to-end to ensure that diversity and inclusion is considered at every step of the process. As part of our global recruitment process, hiring managers must have a diverse candidate short list. If this is not met, it must be approved as an exception (with rationale) by our Global COO.

- Training for recruiters and hiring managers on LGBTQ+ inclusion and awareness.

Including these points can demonstrate a more targeted approach towards attracting LGBTQ+ candidates, complementing the inclusive framework you already have in place.

column8:
Certainly! Here's a summary of the responsibilities for LGBTQ+ DE&I in your organization based on the selected answers in Q1:

1. **Executive Committee**: Provides overall oversight and strategic direction for DE&I initiatives through the Global Inclusion Council. They ensure that LGBTQ+ inclusion is integrated at the highest level of leadership and governance.

2. **Human Resources**: Leads key areas related to LGBTQ+ inclusion, such as offering inclusive benefits, managing talent acquisition and development with an inclusive lens, and collaborating closely with employee resource groups (ERGs) and various business units to support LGBTQ+ DE&I goals.

3. **Diversity & Inclusion Team**: Responsible for designing and implementing the firm-wide DEI strategy, including LGBTQ+ initiatives. They work in partnership with internal and external stakeholders to advance inclusion efforts.

4. **Employee Resource Groups (ERGs)**: Employee-led groups like BBH Pride act as grassroots drivers of DE&I strategies specific to LGBTQ+ matters. BBH Pride functions as a connected global team with active presence across multiple US and European offices, facilitating community engagement and support.

These roles collectively support a comprehensive approach to LGBTQ+ diversity, equity, and inclusion throughout the organization.

column81: If yes, please name the policy and/or actions that your organisation is taking to reduce bias in the recruitment process and support for line managers.
column82: Manager Training: To help mitigate bias throughout the process, hiring managers with open requisitions complete unconscious bias interview training and evaluate candidates across a structured interview process that leverages competency-based interview questions and incorporates a diverse panel. Job Descriptions: We take great care to create gender-neutral job descriptions that properly scope roles — focusing beyond any narrow, specialized requirements to also consider broader capabilities, transferable skillsets, and long-term leadership skills that are beneficial for the team Diverse Candidate Pools: We seek out a diverse slate of candidates for our positions and identify our applicants from a variety of sources. Through partnerships with our BANCs, schools, external partners, and online communities, we work to ensure we have the broadest reach to talent available in the marketplace Competency-Based Interview Process: During our interviews, we leverage competency-based questions that focus on assessing a candidate’s ability or experience through actual events. By focusing on job relevant behaviors, a competency-based approach helps us ensure greater objectivity, accuracy, and consistency when interviewing multiple candidates for a position. Diverse Panel of Interviewers: To further mitigate unconscious bias, we strive for job candidates to meet with a diverse panel of interviewers.

column11: For each of the selected stakeholder groups in Q3, please describe who they are and how they are measured against LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objectives. Please confirm that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column12: Board: Progress against the D&I Strategy is reported to the Board on a 6 monthly basis. The Board provides challenge and feedback on progress, holding the Executive Committee to account on progress against the strategy. All colleagues are invited to take part in our employee engagement survey, and a sub-set of the survey forms the Inclusion Index. The overall responsibility and accountability for year-on-year improvement is held at the Board and Exec Committee level. In addition, each Exec Committee member is held accountable for improvement in their respective Inclusion Index score within their area of responsibility. The M&G inclusion index is cascaded from Exec Management to each people manager with a team of more than 10 people to be able to track year on year improvement of colleague inclusion within their respective teams. The inclusion index is analysed across many aspects of diversity including LGBT+ to ensure there is no significant difference in treatment of the feeling of inclusion of colleagues. If a difference is identified, then those individual teams/managers work with HR to put a plan in place focusing on improving inclusion based on the feedback provided by colleagues. Executive Committee: Louise Shield is the Executive Sponsor of the LGBT+ pillar of the D&I Strategy. Progress against the D&I Strategy is reported to the Executive Committee on a 6 monthly basis, and they are collectively responsible for progress against it. The Executive Committee and direct reports have specific objectives set relating to progress against D&I targets. Senior/Non-Exec Management: Fintan Bannon is the Executive Sponsor for the M&G Pride Network. All Senior leaders reporting directly to an Executive Committee member have objectives set relating to progress against the D&I targets. Other Senior Management have responsibility to disseminate and support D&I events and information with their teams. HR Teams have responsibility to ensure all policies are equitable and non-biased, e.g. parental leave policy, which are written to be gender neutral and have seen an increased uptake from LGBT+ parents and families over the preceding years. The HR Team have also actively embedded D&I into their plans (e.g. recruitment, talent management, learning & development) and are responsible for and have performance measured against delivery The Diversity & Inclusion Team have responsibility for delivery against the D&I Strategy and have performance measured against delivery. The Employee Resource Groups continue to partner on intersectionality across all aspects of diversity including LGBT+, an example of which is a recent collaboration with our Pride Network and Mind Matters, our mental health network, exploring eating disorders and how this can impact the LGBT+ Community.
column13: Evidence that well-distributed, articulated and formalised accountabilities that are met with both ambitious targets and the required systems to communicate the impact to wider business.-- LGBTGreat/Lauren /dFri, 02 Aug 2024 10:57:14 GMT|

column17: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column18: We have a clear ambition of what we want our culture to be and how we want working at M&G to feel for everyone every day: - Tell it like it is - Move forward together - Own it now … with care and integrity. We do all of this in a safe, trusting and inclusive environment where colleagues can speak up if something is wrong and feel able to challenge, knowing appropriate action will be taken. The “how” as well as the “what” is an important part of the performance review process, and underpins the culture at M&G. The “how” and the “what” are culminated in a performance appraisal rating, which influences pay and reward decisions. Employee Resource Group Leaders are expected to include their contributions to the M&G Pride network in their performance planning and year end appraisal conversations with their line managers as part of their performance review discussions. In addition, recognition for those employees who go above and beyond to support an inclusive culture are recognised at M&G’s annual Inclusion Awards, which are hosted and presented by the CEO and members of the Exec Committee. The Award categories are: Role Model of the Year; Rising Star; Network Member of the Year; Inclusion Champion; Wellbeing Champion; Business Impact Champion - a "People's Choice" category, where the winner is voted for by colleagues across the whole business. Many of the nominations include colleagues who are being recognised for their work on LGBT+ inclusion and are visible role models in the community. The Awards are celebrated prominently across TAP, our global communication channel. Previous nominees, finalists and winners have included colleagues championing LGBT+ inclusion. Our colleague recognition app, “Say Thanks”, allows colleagues to say thanks to other colleagues for role modelling our behaviours. It provides a platform to share stories, success and recognise colleagues who are bringing our purpose to life. The app uploads the recognition into Workday, our HR system, to help support mid-year and end of year performance conversations.
column19: This demonstrates a comprehensive and integrated approach to recognising and rewarding LGBTQ+ DE&I efforts at M&G which are clearly embedded in the organisation's culture and values and subsequently reflected in formalised performance management.-- LGBTGreat/Lauren /dFri, 02 Aug 2024 10:57:14 GMT|
column20:
Your organisation recognises and rewards employees supporting LGBTQ+ diversity, equity, and inclusion (DE&I) through several structured and visible initiatives:

1. **Performance Reviews:** Contributions to LGBTQ+ support, such as involvement with the M&G Pride network, are integrated into employees’ performance planning and year-end appraisal discussions. The performance appraisal rating, which includes the "how" (behaviours) along with the "what" (results), influences pay and reward decisions.

2. **Inclusion Awards:** M&G hosts annual Inclusion Awards presented by the CEO and Executive Committee, with categories including Role Model of the Year, Rising Star, Network Member of the Year, Inclusion Champion, Wellbeing Champion, Business Impact Champion, and a People’s Choice award voted by colleagues. Many nominees and winners are recognised specifically for their contributions to LGBTQ+ inclusion.

3. **Internal Communication:** Awards and recognition are prominently celebrated across TAP, the organisation’s global communication channel, raising visibility and encouraging a culture of inclusion.

column36: Recruitment & Selection All of our job adverts specifically state the following towards the top of the advert: " We have a diverse workforce and an inclusive culture at M&G plc, underpinned by our policies and our employee-led networks who provide networking opportunities, advice and support for the diverse communities our colleagues represent. (For example see evidence folder ”Yammer page posts on promoting external events and resources”.) Sponsorship of external events such as the Career masterclass Stretch Conference and Everywoman’s Global Summit provides additional opportunity. Pay, Reward and Benefits Our Private Medical Insurance includes gender reassignment, with Transitioning at Work supporting manager guidance in place. Our Employee Assistance Programme provides fully confidential support to our colleagues and their immediate families with all aspects of their lives, including a 24/7 online GP, mental health support service, support, advice and more. Our HR policies are written in inclusive language and designed to be market leading, for example, our parental leave policy which provides equal amount of parental leave (6 months) to anyone becoming a parent, regardless of gender and regardless of how they become a parent (e.g. natural birth, surrogacy, adoption etc.). column68:
It sounds like your organization is actively encouraging colleagues to review and update their self-ID diversity data through an ongoing campaign. To further enhance comfort and increase participation in disclosing DE&I information, you might consider complementing this campaign with strategies such as:

- **Communications emphasizing confidentiality and purpose:** Clearly explain how the data will be used, stored securely, and how it benefits both individuals and the organization.
- **Leadership involvement:** Have leaders share their own self-ID experiences to build trust and normalize disclosure.
- **Anonymous feedback opportunities:** Provide channels where employees can express concerns or suggestions about the self-ID process.
- **Inclusive language and options:** Ensure the data fields reflect a wide range of identities and allow for nuanced self-description.
- **Regular updates and reminders:** Keep the campaign visible over time to encourage late disclosures and updates.

column81: If yes, please name the policy and/or actions that your organisation is taking to reduce bias in the recruitment process and support for line managers.
column82: Recruitment principles and D&I Guide for Hiring Managers sets out how we go about reducing bias during the recruitment process. M&G’s Recruitment Charter is a set of principles to: • ensure our roles appeal to a broad range of candidates • to help overcome unconscious bias in selection and appointment. In relation to Apprenticeship recruitment: - All colleagues involved with the selection are recommended to complete online “unconscious bias‟ courses and we dedicate part of the assessor workshop to this topic; - Assessors are briefed to challenge each other for bias throughout the process; - Apprentice job descriptions are checked carefully against gender decoder, to remove certain adjectives, or words that can be seen as masculine language or stereotypically gendered words; - CV's are reviewed "blind", with no personal characteristics included; - We use a defined competency based interview script in interviews to ensure all candidates are asked the same questions for consistency and transparency; - We use psychometric tests which are seen as good predictors of performance; - We ensure diverse interview panels; - We challenge „Likability‟ during the final selection stage and focus on evidence; In relation to Graduate recruitment: As well as point above. - Bias training provided for all assessors; - there is no CV screening until final stage; - We undertake a strengths based assessment centre, which includes a mixture of strength based and competency based questions. In relation to experienced hires, all recruiters have completed an unconscious bias training course, and managers are provided with a D&I guide to recruitment
column83: This demonstrates an impressively mature and exhaustive approach to ensuing equity and equality at all stages in the hiring process and clear mechanisms are in place to eliminate unconscious bias.-- LGBTGreat/Lauren /dFri, 02 Aug 2024 16:17:13 GMT|

The evidences we require include:

- Confirmation of whether the firm is a signatory or member of recognized equality benchmarks such as the National Equality Standard, Disability Confident Scheme, Law Society Diversity and Inclusion Charter, or Stonewall Workplace Equality Index. If not currently a member, evidence of commitment to becoming a signatory or member, specifying which benchmark(s) the firm is working towards, how, and by when they plan to meet the required standards.

column148: We have a "How We Work" policy, of which Dress code is one of the areas covered. All of our policies are written in gender neutral language and are reviewed on an annual basis. We ask that you consider the expectations of our customers, colleagues, or partners that you will be interacting with on each working day as well as considering if you are working from an M&G office or your home. column151: If yes, please describe how this was achieved and attach copies of your benefits.
column152: At M&G we strive to be market leading in our benefits and policies. All of our policies are written to be inclusive of all colleagues. For example, our Inspiring Families policy is designed to be inclusive and all encompassing. An overview of our Inspiring Families policy is below: Being inclusive – an overview to our approach for inspiring families Being inclusive is an important part of our culture, and we want to support all colleagues. Planning a family is different for everyone, and we’re here to support whatever form that takes. If you, your partner or surrogate are undergoing fertility treatment, we provide you paid leave. Families also come in all shapes and sizes and we believe all parents deserve the same opportunity to spend time with their new arrival. We want to keep it simple. However you’re becoming a parent (surrogacy, you/your partner giving birth or adoption), you’ll get an equal amount of paid parental leave to care for your child. And if you’re already a parent, there are other types of family leave available too. Our polices are gender neutral, for example our recent Menopause policy has the following approach: Our approach Perimenopause, menopause and other hormone imbalance conditions, are a natural stage of life that can affect people of any sex, all gender identities, trans and non-binary employees usually between the age of 45 to 50 years but can also happen anytime in someone’s life, for example the menopause or other hormone imbalance conditions may be brought on due to medical reasons We cover gender reassignment within our private medical insurance, and have a transitioning at work policy.
