column6: Executives: Since EquiLend's inception, our Executives have played a leading role in fostering Diversity & Inclusion efforts at EquiLend. EquiLend's CEO Brian Lamb and EquiLend's CFO Paul Nigrelli have both been featured on LGBT Great's Top 100 Executive Allies list in recognition of their support of LGBT+ inclusion initiatives. Human Resources: EquiLend's Diversity & Inclusion Committee is co-chaired by two members of the Human Resources team at any given time, thus ensuring the Committee's alignment with company D&I strategy and the HR Team's ability to promote the Committee and its activities among EquiLend employees. Diversity & Inclusion & Other Employees: EquiLend's global D&I Committee is comprised of employees across teams, seniority levels, and office locations. Each employee brings their ideas and perspectives to the work of the Committee, and new employees across global locations are invited to join the Committee.
column8:
Certainly! Here's a summary of the responsibilities for LGBTQ+ DE&I in your organisation based on the provided response:

1. **Executives**:  
   - Lead and champion Diversity & Inclusion efforts from the top level.  
   - Act as visible allies and role models for LGBTQ+ inclusion.  
   - Examples include the CEO Brian Lamb and CFO Paul Nigrelli being recognized on LGBT Great's Top 100 Executive Allies list, highlighting their active support.

2. **Human Resources**:  
   - Co-chair the Diversity & Inclusion Committee to align its work with the overall company D&I strategy.  
   - Promote the Committee’s initiatives and activities among employees.  
   - Facilitate the integration of D&I efforts into broader HR processes and employee engagement.

3. **Diversity & Inclusion Committee & Other Employees**:  
   - Comprise a global team from various departments, seniority levels, and locations, promoting diverse perspectives.  
   - Contribute ideas and actively participate in advancing LGBTQ+ inclusion.  
   - Encourage ongoing recruitment of new committee members to maintain representation and fresh insights.

column17: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column18: As part of EquiLend's annual Pride Month celebration, we conducted a series of Pride quizzes throughout the June to encourage employees to learn about LGBT+ history, important dates, identities and more. The employees that came in 1st, 2nd and 3rd place were given the opportunity to select the LGBT+ charity of their choice and EquiLend donated on their behalf. Throughout the year, EquiLend also matches up to $250 USD per employee in donations to any charity of the employees choosing. For Pride Month, the D&I and Charity Committees coordinated a weekend volunteer day in NYC in partnership with the organization God's Love We Deliver, which holds historic ties to the LGBT+ community. All employees who signed up were offered an extra vacation day in recognition of their volunteer service.
column20:
Your organisation recognises and rewards employees supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I efforts through several initiatives:

- During Pride Month, you hold a series of Pride quizzes to educate employees on LGBTQ+ history and identities, rewarding the top three participants by donating to their chosen LGBTQ+ charities on their behalf.
- Throughout the year, you match employee donations up to $250 USD to any charity, encouraging philanthropic engagement.
- Additionally, for Pride Month, your D&I and Charity Committees organise a volunteer day with God's Love We Deliver, a charity with historic ties to the LGBTQ+ community, and employees who volunteer receive an extra vacation day as recognition.

These efforts both celebrate awareness and actively support the LGBTQ+ community while acknowledging and rewarding employee participation.

column36: LGBTQ+ Talent Attraction /Recruitment: At EquiLend we are dedicated to attracting and supporting LGBTQ+ talent through a variety of targeted initiatives. We also formally acknowledge and celebrate our Executive Allies and Gamechangers/Role Models/Allies both internally and externally, and encourage our employees to leverage LGBT Great's mentorship program. Learning & Development: EquiLend provides at least one annual LGBT+ diversity & inclusion training to all employees globally, aiming to create a workplace where everyone feels respected and valued, inclusive of their sexual orientation or gender identity. Communications (Internal/External): The Diversity & Inclusion Committee works closely with EquiLend's Marketing team to publish a consistent schedule of D&I-related content both internally and externally. Different members of the D&I Committee regularly contribute to internal newsletters on specific D&I-related themes. EquiLend's external posts on social channels publicly reflect EquiLend's commitment to championing Diversity & Inclusion and enhancing our practices.

column46: Discrimination based on sexual orientation policy: As EquiLend is a global company, our policies vary based on region, in accordance with local legislation and anti-discrimination laws. In the US, all employees must agree to the Policy Against Harassment and Discrimination and Retaliation which prohibits discrimination, acts of harassment and any other conduct that creates an intimidating, hostile or offensive work environment, or unreasonably interferes with work performance based on an individual’s actual or perceived age, race, physical characteristics historically associated with race (such as natural hair, hair texture, hair type and protective hairstyles), color, national origin or immigration status, citizenship, work authorization status or the period of such a status, ancestry, sex, gender (including pregnancy, childbirth or medical condition related to pregnancy or childbirth), reproductive health decision making, gender identity or expression, sexual orientation, religious creed, physical or mental disability, medical condition, genetic information, HIV testing status, status as a victim of a crime of violence (such as domestic, sexual, or gender violence), marital status, familial status, veteran status, military status, Civil Air Patrol status or any other characteristic protected by federal, state or local law. Discrimination based on gender identity and expression policy: As EquiLend is a global company, our policies vary based on region, in accordance with local legislation and anti-discrimination laws. In the US, all employees must agree to the Policy Against Harassment and Discrimination and Retaliation which prohibits discrimination, acts of harassment and any other conduct that creates an intimidating, hostile or offensive work environment, or unreasonably interferes with work performance based on an individual’s actual or perceived age, race, physical characteristics historically associated with race (such as natural hair, hair texture, hair type and protective hairstyles), color, national origin or immigration status, citizenship, work authorization status or the period of such a status, ancestry, sex, gender (including pregnancy, childbirth or medical condition related to pregnancy or childbirth), reproductive health decision making, gender identity or expression, sexual orientation, religious creed, physical or mental disability, medical condition, genetic information, HIV testing status, status as a victim of a crime of violence (such as domestic, sexual, or gender violence), marital status, familial status, veteran status, military status, Civil Air Patrol status or any other characteristic protected by federal, state or local law. Inclusive parental leave policy (i.e. shared maternity & parental leave): EquiLend offers gender-inclusive paid parental leave globally across all regional locations. Policies vary based on region. Adoption leave policy: EquiLend's paid parental leave policies apply identically to employees who are in the process of adoption.

column5: For each of the selected answers in Q1, please describe what responsibilities they have for LGBTQ+ DE&I in your organisation.
column6: Board – Our CEO presents a people and culture update at every Board meeting, which covers diversity matters including LGBT+. This provides the Board with oversight of employee engagement, diversity, equity and inclusion. Robyn Grew is the senior sponsor for the Pride@Man network and is very visible internally and externally in the drive for LGBT+ inclusion Executive management – our ExCo are very supportive of inclusion for all not just LGBT+ and Carol Ward, President Man Discretionary is the senior advisor of the Pride@ Man network. Members of our ExCo also make up part of our Drive (global DEI network) SteerCo. People Team (previously HR & Talent) - are strong drivers of LGBTQ+ inclusion and continue to work with employees and the Drive networks in particular to review policies in the firm. Many members of the People team are also members of the Pride@Man network. D&I – the Pride@Man Network is one of several employee resource groups at Man, who drive forward LGBT+ initiatives with the main aim of creating an environment where everyone feels comfortable to bring their true selves to the office every day. Non-executive line management- All people managers have a set of ‘expectations’ and one of these is culture and inclusion, with the responsibility to their direct reports to create an environment of tolerance, understanding and safety where everyone feels like they ‘belong’.
column8:
Here is a summary of the responsibilities for LGBTQ+ DE&I for each selected group in your organisation:

- **Board**: Receives regular updates on diversity, equity, and inclusion (DE&I) matters including LGBTQ+ from the CEO. Provides oversight on employee engagement and DE&I. Senior sponsor Robyn Grew champions the Pride@Man network and LGBT+ inclusion both internally and externally.

- **Executive Management (ExCo)**: Supports inclusion broadly including LGBTQ+. Carol Ward, President Man Discretionary, acts as senior advisor to the Pride@Man network. ExCo members also participate in the global DEI network SteerCo, contributing to strategic direction.

- **People Team (HR & Talent)**: Actively drives LGBTQ+ inclusion by collaborating with employees and DEI networks like Drive. Reviews and updates firm policies to support DE&I. Many People team members participate in the Pride@Man network.

- **Diversity & Inclusion (D&I) / Pride@Man Network**: Leads LGBTQ+ initiatives aimed at fostering an inclusive environment where employees feel comfortable being their authentic selves at work.

- **Non-executive Line Management**: Held accountable through clear expectations to foster culture and inclusion. Responsible for creating safe, tolerant, and understanding environments for their direct reports, ensuring a sense of belonging.

Let me know if you need a more detailed breakdown or further clarification!
column11: For each of the selected stakeholder groups in Q3, please describe who they are and how they are measured against LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objectives. Please confirm that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column12: The Board - For the CEO and CFO's bonuses 30% of the annual bonus is awarded based on qualitative ‘strategic and personal objectives' and 'ESG-related objectives' which includes DE&I measures. (pg 104 of Annual Report) DE&I Team - Our global diversity network, Drive is managed by the Corporate Sustainability Team and we take part in a number of diversity benchmarking exercises such as the Diversity Project Goals and Progress Tool and the iiBT. The annual Thriving at Work Assessment now has a strong focus on the intersectionality of diversity and wellbeing which we also believe as part of our strategy. Employee Resource Groups - The Drive networks (including Pride@Man) set themselves goals for the year that align with the 3 pillars of inclusion, recognition and community that make up our DE&I strategy.
column14:
Here is a summary for each of the selected stakeholder groups regarding who they are and how they are measured against LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objectives:

1. The Board  
   - Who they are: The Board includes senior executives such as the CEO and CFO.  
   - Measurement: 30% of the CEO and CFO’s annual bonuses are tied to qualitative strategic and personal objectives, including ESG-related objectives with DE&I measures, as outlined on page 104 of the Annual Report.  

2. DE&I Team  
   - Who they are: The global diversity network, called Drive, is managed by the Corporate Sustainability Team.  
   - Measurement: They participate in diversity benchmarking exercises such as the Diversity Project’s Goals and Progress Tool and the Inclusive Index Benchmarking Tool (iiBT). Additionally, the annual Thriving at Work Assessment measures the intersectionality of diversity and wellbeing, contributing to the DE&I strategy.  

3. Employee Resource Groups (ERGs)  
   - Who they are: Drive networks, including Pride@Man, are employee-led groups supporting diverse communities.  
   - Measurement: These groups set annual goals aligned with the three pillars of the DE&I strategy — inclusion, recognition, and community.

column23: For each of the selected responses in Q7, please describe what proactive actions have been taken in the last 12 months by individuals and the organisation.
column24: Our CEO Robyn Grew is a proud role model for the LGBTQ+ community and has been quoted in several publications about being an out CEO. She also has an active role as a senior sponsor for Pride@Man, and continues to take part in internal events to discuss her career journey and give her thoughts on allyship and sponsorship. Information on LGBT+ employee resource group/network – Information on the Pride@Man network is issued to ALL new joiners as part of their welcome pack, it is also reiterated in the 1:1 new joiner check-ins (at 30 days and 90 days) Pride@Man also has a buddy system which lists members of the network that employees can approach for safe space conversations concerning LGBTQ+ issues and topics. All new employees are directed to all our internal policies including those related to LGBT+ eg. Gender identity, use of gender pronouns, parental leave and adoption leave. There is opportunity to engage in LGBT+ training and development. All employees can attend LGBT Great sessions, and or sign up to events and webinars put on by the Pride@Man network to raise awareness of LGBT+ matters. Our compliance training also includes Dignity and Respect at Work training which is mandatory for all employees.
column26:
In the past 12 months, the following proactive actions have been taken by individuals and the organisation regarding LGBTQ+ inclusion:

- The CEO, Robyn Grew, has actively served as a senior sponsor for the Pride@Man network, participated in internal events sharing her career journey, and spoken publicly as an out LGBTQ+ CEO to promote visibility and allyship.

- The Pride@Man network information is provided to all new employees through their welcome packs and reinforced during one-on-one check-ins at 30 and 90 days, ensuring early awareness and engagement.

- The Pride@Man network operates a buddy system where employees can connect with designated members for safe space conversations on LGBTQ+ topics.

- New employees receive full information about internal policies related to LGBTQ+ issues, including gender identity, use of gender pronouns, parental leave, and adoption leave.

- The organisation offers opportunities for employees to engage in LGBTQ+ training and development, such as attending LGBT Great sessions and participating in events or webinars organized by the Pride@Man network to raise awareness.

- Mandatory compliance training for all employees includes Dignity and Respect at Work modules that reinforce an inclusive and respectful workplace environment.

column36: Our DEI programme has 3 pillars to advance our strategy: inclusion, recognition and community. We achieve this through educational and inclusive events, providing further education through toolkits, blogs and other forms of media; and finally through philanthropic efforts through volunteering with charities, schools, universities and other local communities. Our People team has considered the LGBT+ community for our benefits, including providing equal adoption leave benefits. The People team continue to review employee benefits each year to ensure we remain an employer of choice, and includes plans for a Transitioning at Work Policy in order to help employees going through this major life change. Our Comms teams have a process in place where they check in with relevant communities on issues that will impact them to ensure that messages are communicated appropriately, sensitively and effectively.

column81: If yes, please name the policy and/or actions that your organisation is taking to reduce bias in the recruitment process and support for line managers.
column82: Our recruitment efforts focus on reaching and attracting a diverse group of candidates. We have a diversity-focused recruitment policy in place to ensure that we have diverse interview panels and candidate lists across all roles. We run diversity-focused graduate recruitment events for underrepresented groups in full time education, and work with targeted university networks to enable our success in this area. We know the benefits that a diverse workforce brings and the numerous highly qualified candidates that are overlooked by traditional recruitment channels. We have therefore taken a series of steps both to recruit from the broadest pool of talent possible, and then to make sure that we retain these employees. For example, we work with LGBT Great as an active inclusion recruitment partner.

We have had a number of social media posts shared on LinkedIn that promote our Pride@Man network, and our CEO Robyn Grew has been quoted in multiple publications as a great LGBT+ role model in the world of finance. We work with a number of diverse recruitment specialists to ensure that we have a wider pool of applicants from diverse backgrounds.
column89: Please describe and attach examples of the content covered by this training.
column90: At Man, you are expected to hold yourself and others to the highest standards of conduct and adhere to Man's strict zero-tolerance policy for discrimination, harassment and victimisation. "Dignity and Respect at Work" is a mandatory compliance training designed to instill Man Group's core principles, focusing on fostering an inclusive and respectful workplace environment. The course covers essential topics such as anti-discrimination and anti-harassment laws, ensuring employees are well-informed about legal frameworks and their responsibilities. Participants will gain a comprehensive understanding of Man's key policies and procedures related to these issues, including how to effectively implement them in daily interactions and decision-making processes. The training emphasizes the importance of maintaining dignity and respect among colleagues, promoting an atmosphere where all individuals feel valued and safe. A crucial component of the course is educating employees on Man's complaint reporting procedure. This ensures that any instances of discrimination or harassment are promptly addressed and resolved in accordance with the organization's standards. By understanding how to report and respond to complaints, employees can contribute to a culture of accountability and continuous improvement. Ultimately, the training aims to equip employees with the knowledge and tools necessary to apply Man's principles consistently, thereby perpetuating an inclusive and welcoming workplace. Through this course, Man Group reaffirms its commitment to creating an environment where diversity is celebrated and every employee is empowered to thrive.

column6: The responsibilities for LGBTQ+ initiatives at Moody's are distributed across various groups and individuals within the organization: Moody's board has several responsibilities regarding LGBTQ+ initiatives, which include recognizing and supporting the Pride Business Resource Groups (BRG) that advocates for a work environment respectful and supportive of LGBTQ+ professionals. The board is also involved in implementing inclusion strategies through the Moody's Diversity Council, which consists of senior leaders. This council ensures that strategic priorities are actualized with checks and balances instituted by a global executive council and regional councils in EMEA. Moreover, the board's involvement extends to supporting significant milestones such as earning a 100% from the Human Rights Campaign on its Corporate Equality Index since 2013 and being recognized as a top employer for LGBTQ+ people The Executive Leadership Team and senior leaders are involved in setting and agreeing on the LGBTQ+ inclusion strategy yearly through the strategic planning process. They are expected to demonstrate how they have increased inclusion in their teams as part of their performance management. The People Team and the Inclusion Team develop, govern, and execute the Inclusion strategy for Moody's in partnership with BRGs, leadership, Global and Regional Executive Sponsors, and every Moody's employee. They are entrusted with ensuring every person at the company feels valued and accepted. The Business Resource Groups (BRGs) are dedicated to supporting and advocating for employees from various backgrounds, including LGBTQ+ employees. They provide forums, resources, and programming to promote understanding and allyship. The Pride BRG’s mission is to advocate a work environment that respects, welcomes and supports lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and non-binary individuals, and enables them to perform to their fullest potential as well as continuing to promote the concept of being an ally. All employees are encouraged to promote an inclusive workplace culture on their teams, participate in Inclusion initiatives/BRG events..
column8:
The responsibilities for LGBTQ+ DE&I at Moody's are assigned as follows:

- **Moody's Board**: Supports and recognizes the Pride Business Resource Group (BRG), implements inclusion strategies via the Diversity Council composed of senior leaders, oversees strategic priorities with global and regional councils, and supports milestones such as maintaining a 100% rating from the Human Rights Campaign’s Corporate Equality Index since 2013 and being recognized as a top employer for LGBTQ+ people.

- **Executive Leadership Team and Senior Leaders**: Set and agree on the LGBTQ+ inclusion strategy annually during strategic planning, and demonstrate inclusion progress within their teams as part of performance management.

- **People Team and Inclusion Team**: Develop, govern, and execute Moody’s Inclusion strategy collaboratively with BRGs, leadership, and executive sponsors, ensuring all employees feel valued and accepted.

- **Business Resource Groups (BRGs), including the Pride BRG**: Support and advocate for LGBTQ+ employees by providing forums, resources, and programs that foster understanding and allyship, advocating for a respectful and inclusive work environment that enables LGBTQ+ individuals to thrive.

- **All Employees**: Encouraged to foster an inclusive workplace culture within their teams and actively participate in inclusion initiatives and BRG events.
column11: For each of the selected stakeholder groups in Q3, please describe who they are and how they are measured against LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objectives. Please confirm that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column12: Moody's measures its LGBTQ+ inclusion progress using the Inclusion Scorecard, which is a comprehensive tool designed to track and measure the company's diversity and inclusion efforts. The scorecard includes various objectives and key results measures that are aligned with the company's strategic priorities. For instance, one of the objectives is to ensure that 85% of open positions will have a diverse slate of candidates for the first round of interviews. This is a new measure introduced to track the progress of inclusion in the hiring process. The scorecard also includes measures for the success and growth of women, empowering Business Resource Groups (BRGs) to champion the culture of inclusion, and the implementation of inclusive benefits like the Global, Gender-Neutral Parental Leave policy. The Inclusion Scorecard is connected to individual and team objectives through Moody's Grow, Perform, Succeed (GPS) objective-setting and development planning performance management approach. Employees are encouraged to work with their manager to connect their individual and team objectives to the company's strategic and operational objectives outlined on the Corporate Scorecard. The TIDE programme (Talent, Inclusion, Diversity, and Equality) likely contributes to the Inclusion Scorecard by supporting the company's commitment to creating a diverse and inclusive workplace. The specific goals and objectives of the TIDE programme would align with the broader DE&I strategy and be reviewed annually to measure progress. Overall, the Inclusion Scorecard serves as an "internal benchmark" to hold all stakeholders accountable for shared priorities and outcomes related to LGBTQ+ inclusion and broader diversity and inclusion goals.
column13: Evidence of a broad, robust and formalised process in place for measuring and assessing stakeholders' LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objective. The Inclusion Scorecard is a particularly mature and data-driven approach which LGBT Great would like to commend Moody's for implementing.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dMon, 07 Oct 2024 09:40:06 GMT|

column17: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column18: Moody's recognizes and rewards employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I through various channels: Emails from the Chief Inclusion Officer: Employees receive emails from the Chief Inclusion Officer that may include recognition of their contributions to LGBTQ+ DE&I initiatives. Award Nominations: Employees can be nominated for internal (at BRG Summit by the Office of Inclusion) and external awards that acknowledge their efforts in promoting LGBTQ+ DE&I within the company. Attendance at Related Events: Employees are encouraged to attend events such as the British LGBT Awards and LGBT Great 'Together with Pride' event, which can serve as both a form of recognition and a means to further their understanding and support of LGBTQ+ issues. Annual BRG Summit in New York: The summit is an opportunity for Business Resource Group (BRG) members to come together, share best practices, and be recognized for their work over the past year. Promotion in the Inclusion Digest: The Inclusion Digest is a communication channel that highlights the efforts and achievements of employees in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I. Recognition Tool Launch in September: This upcoming tool will provide another platform for acknowledging and celebrating the contributions of employees to our Inclusion efforts including LGBTQ+. These initiatives demonstrate Moody's commitment to creating an inclusive environment and recognizing the valuable contributions of its employees towards LGBTQ+ diversity, equity, and inclusion.
column19: Evidence of a comprehensive and integrated approach to recognising and rewarding LGBTQ+ DE&I efforts, embedded in the Moody's culture and values and reflected in formalised performance management.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dMon, 07 Oct 2024 09:40:06 GMT|
column20:
Moody's recognises and rewards employees supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I through multiple initiatives:

- **Emails from the Chief Inclusion Officer:** Highlighting individual contributions to LGBTQ+ DE&I efforts.
- **Award Nominations:** Employees may be nominated for internal awards (such as at the BRG Summit by the Office of Inclusion) and external awards recognising their work promoting LGBTQ+ inclusion.
- **Attendance at LGBTQ+ Events:** Encouraging participation in events like the British LGBT Awards and LGBT Great 'Together with Pride,' fostering appreciation and awareness.
- **Annual BRG Summit in New York:** An opportunity for Business Resource Group members to share best practices and receive recognition for their achievements.
- **Inclusion Digest:** Featuring employee efforts and accomplishments in LGBTQ+ DE&I as part of ongoing communications.
- **Recognition Tool Launch (September):** A forthcoming platform to further acknowledge and celebrate employee contributions to Inclusion initiatives, including LGBTQ+ DE&I.

These efforts reflect Moody's commitment to valuing and encouraging employee involvement in fostering an inclusive workplace.

column24: The Moody's Global Inclusion Council is chaired by the CEO and includes members from Moody's Corporation Operating Committee, which is a group of senior leaders responsible for overseeing the company's operations and ensuring the implementation of its strategic goals. This committee plays a crucial role in guiding the company's direction and making key decisions that impact various aspects of the business.. Global Executive Sponsors and Regional Executive Sponsors: These senior leaders play a crucial role in advancing inclusion at Moody's. They work closely with the Inclusion team and Business Resource Groups (BRGs) to ensure that events and initiatives are aligned with the focus areas of Moody's Inclusion Strategy. Mentoring and Reverse Mentoring: We hope to reinstate our reverse mentoring programme in the coming year. Moody's collaborates with external partners such as LGBT Great. This partnership provides LGBTQ+ employees and allies with opportunities to participate in mentorship programmes that connect mentees with mentors across different regions and organizations. These programmes are designed to help participants network among peers, build confidence, and learn new skills. The collaboration with LGBT Great is part of Moody's broader effort to support LGBTQ+ talent and promote an inclusive workplace culture Internal and External Training and Coaching: The LGBTQ+ training at Moody's is designed to cultivate a supportive and understanding environment for LGBTQ+ individuals in the workplace. One notable session is "Together with Pride: The History, Vibrancy, and Transformative Impact of LGBTQ+ Pride," which delves into the global history and importance of Pride, including key legislation affecting LGBTQ+ rights in various countries. The training also covers concepts such as intersectionality and allyship within the Pride context, and discusses the various facets of Pride, including celebration, protest, and community. In addition to LGBTQ+ training, Moody's has launched the Stand for Inclusion training series. This series provides practical guidance to help employees apply inclusive practices every day. Access to LGBTQ+ Focused Conferences and Events: Leaders are encouraged to attend conferences and events that focus on LGBTQ+ issues, providing them with insights and best practices from outside the organization. Moody's Pride BRG: The Pride BRG hosts monthly steering committee meetings attended by the executive sponsor, co-chairs, secretary, treasurer, events and communications leads, DE&I regional manager, and other active volunteer members. These meetings serve as a platform for discussing and advocating for LGBTQ+ issues within the company. These efforts collectively contribute to a deeper understanding and commitment to LGBTQ+ inclusion among Moody's leadership, fostering a culture of respect and support for LGBTQ+ professionals.
column25: Evidence of a comprehensive and multi-faceted approach to leadership development on LGBTQ+ issues including proactive actions, sustained engagement and specific outcomes.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dMon, 07 Oct 2024 09:40:06 GMT|

column35: For each of the selected options in Q3, please describe how your LGBTQ+ DE&I strategy addresses each option.
column36: Moody's LGBTQ+ inclusion strategy is a comprehensive approach that addresses various aspects of the workplace to ensure an inclusive environment for all employees. Workforce Planning: The strategy includes objectives to ensure a diverse slate of candidates for interviews, aiming for 85% of open positions to meet this criterion, which includes diverse interview panels and self-ID campaigns to reflect the communities where Moody's operates. LGBTQ+ Talent Attraction/Recruitment: The strategy emphasizes the measurement of the efficiency of various recruitment partnerships and the re-launch of self-ID campaigns in the US and UK. Moody’s implemented Textio: an augmented writing tool that brings the world’s most advanced language insights into our hiring and employer brand content. This tool will flag biased and gendered language in job descriptions and will guide our recruiters, HR team members, and hiring managers in real time as they edit each job description on better wording to use that shows inclusivity across various underrepresented groups, including the LGBTQ+ community. This tool will be available to anyone who writes and edits job descriptions to prepare them for posting and recruiting. It ensures a work environment that respects the dignity and worth of each individual and is free from all forms of employment discrimination. Transitioning at Work Policy: Moody's Gender Transition Guidelines support employees considering transitioning in the workplace. Gender Expression/Transition Guide: The Gender Transition Guidelines provide best practices for transitioning employees, including the use of facilities matching their gender identity and recommendations for a smooth transition process. The Discrimination and Harassment Policy, revised as recently as July 20, 2023, ensures a work environment that respects the dignity and worth of each individual and is free from all forms of employment discrimination, including harassment because of sexual orientation, gender identity, gender expression, and other protected characteristics. column65: What campaigns, strategies or approaches has your organisation undertaken to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data?
column66: To ensure employees feel comfortable sharing their self-identification data, Moody's is committed to maintaining the highest standards of data accuracy, retention, and security. The UK Self-ID Campaign outlines specific measures such as: Data Accuracy: Employee Self-Service permissions will be used to maintain data accuracy, allowing fields to be editable by the employee only and viewable by authorized roles. Data Retention: Data will be anonymized during lower instance refreshes and destroyed via DRTM purge seven years after an employee terminates, as per the annual DRTM purge conducted each December. Data Security: Role-Based Permissions will safeguard the data, ensuring that only those with appropriate access can view or edit the data. The data is not exportable unless specific permissions are granted. Furthermore, an FAQ document has been created to address common questions and concerns employees might have regarding the self-identification process. This document clarifies that self-identification is entirely voluntary and explains how to self-identify within WorkWise. It also emphasizes that diverse groups, including LGBTQ+ individuals, are at risk of being undercounted, highlighting the importance of self-identification for accurate representation and support within the company. Moody's assures that all personal data collected will be treated with the utmost confidentiality and used solely for the purpose of advancing DE&I within the organization. The information provided will not be considered in hiring or promotion decisions, ensuring that employees' privacy and professional integrity remain intact. For any further details or concerns, employees are encouraged to refer to the comprehensive Self-Identification FAQ document, which provides in-depth answers to potential queries.

column113: If yes, please describe the process.
column114: Moody's has a process to ensure that policies and communications are inclusive and use inclusive language. The company is committed to embedding inclusion into everything it does to drive innovation and deliver value for its partners and customers. This commitment is reflected in various initiatives and policies aimed at promoting diversity and inclusion within the organization. Moody's Code of Business Conduct (the Code) outlines the ethical principles that Moody’s employees are expected to follow and serves as a foundation for other policies within the company. Moody’s considers it the responsibility of each employee to adhere to the Code and to raise awareness of issues that may compromise the company’s integrity. Additionally, Moody’s managers and corporate directors have the responsibility of fostering a culture where compliance with applicable laws and Moody’s policies is central to our business activities. By following the principles in the Code, Moody’s employees contribute to maintaining a work environment that is open, inclusive, and fair for all. As part of Moody’s Annual Compliance Policy Refresher Training and Certification process, employees are required to certify their compliance with the Code. Moody's recently launched it's Stand for Inclusion Training program that emphasizes the importance of inclusive language and practices. This training is part of a broader effort to modernize ways of working, differentiate capabilities, and power the organization with world-class solutions for a new era of risk. Moody's has an Inclusive Language Guide designed to help make communications more inclusive and reflective of diversity, equality, and inclusion (DE&I) best practices. This guide is intended for use in communications with colleagues, customers, media, and investors. It provides tips and guidelines on using the most inclusive, appropriate, and up-to-date words and phrases when talking about various aspects of identity, such as disability, race and ethnicity, gender identity, and sexual orientation. The guide emphasizes the importance of considering whether mentioning someone's race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, age, or disability is relevant or necessary. It also encourages asking individuals how they would like to be acknowledged if identity comes up in communication. This guide aims to help everyone at Moody's communicate in a way that makes everyone feel included and valued. It is available to all Moody’s leaders: “Inclusive Leadership: Actions You Can Take”, which provides practical steps for leaders to foster an inclusive environment at Moody's. Here are some key actions highlighted in the document. These actions are part of Moody's commitment to creating a workplace that reflects a broad range of cultures, experiences, and backgrounds. The document emphasizes that a diverse workforce bolsters the quality of products and analytical insight and strengthens the understanding of customers globally.

column148: Moody’s UK Employee Handbook has reviewed it’s dress code to ensure that it is LGBTQ+ inclusive, when we address harassment in the workplace. Discrimination and Harassment You should refer to the “How We Treat Each Other” ” section of the “Moody’s Code of Business Conduct”. Examples of prohibited and discriminatory bullying and harassment, include: Making assumptions and judgements about a colleague based on gender identity and gender expression. For example, about their choice of dress; We also refer to choice of dress in our Trans Inclusive Guide - Those who consider themselves gender variant may change their gender expression in terms of how they like to dress, moving between the feminine and masculine ends of the spectrum. Some people also choose to not dress as feminine or masculine and are androgynous. Gender Transition Guide - We do not have a gendered dress code. This means all employees, including trans and non-binary employees can dress as they feel comfortable within the dress code to appear smart and professional. For example, any person of any gender may choose to wear skirts, trousers, make-up, etc.; or a combination thereof. LGBTQIA+ Guide - Gender reassignment: Another way of describing a person’s transition. To undergo gender reassignment usually means to undergo some sort of medical intervention, but it can also mean changing names, pronouns, dressing differently and living in their self-identified gender.

column32:
Yes, the organization supports DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) efforts through the following ways:

- They have a DEI network called Lighthouse, focused on LGBTQ+ and allies, which is hosted on their Engage platform.
- Senior leaders such as Benjamin Brust (Head of General Counsel's Office) and Jonny Black (Chief Commercial & Strategy Officer) currently sponsor the Lighthouse network, with ongoing discussions about additional executive-level sponsorship.
- These sponsors actively participate by writing blogs and serving as visible role models within the community.
- Communication efforts include occasional blogs and use of the Viva Engage platform. Following a DEI reset and National Inclusion Week, these efforts will be intensified.
- The organization runs the “What you see and The real me” campaign, which showcases colleagues from diverse backgrounds. For example, one Lighthouse co-chair was featured in the first seven stories, discussing acceptance and the strength of LGBTQ+ communities and networks in organizations.

column36: L&D is provided through various platforms – please see answer 7 for further information for how our L&D strategy encompasses DEI. Currently on our people system we collect Sexual Orientation data, Gender Identity data (both as binary M/F as required by benefits and local tax) and as inclusive options. We also collect Pronoun usage. This is collected in all locations for which we are able to legally collect the data. This is analysed regularly and on an ad-hock basis for both reporting purposes and for reviewing during change – such as allowing analysis through part of our employee surveys, and when LGBTQ+ topics are on the agenda – such as during key events like National Inclusion week. Communications are done as employee-led via our global lighthouse committee, via specific events from partners such as the previously mentioned benefits or speaker series which have been run, and finally through the central comms team during key events. National inclusion week is being coordinated via the colleague experience team in 2024 including a robust ahead of time, during, and post colleague comms plan covering data, employee involvement, myths and misconceptions, and network information.

column68:
Your organisation has undertaken several campaigns and strategies to improve comfort around disclosing self-identified DE&I data:

- **‘2mins to make a difference’ campaign:** Encouraged all employees to update their Workday (people system) data to help make abrdn a better workplace. This included:
  - A short instructional video explaining how to complete their data and its purpose.
  - Frequent reinforcement through company emails and messages during Q2 and Q3 of 2024.
  - Involvement of Executive Leadership Team (ELT) members, who communicated directly with their business areas to encourage participation. For example:
    - A message during an all-HR townhall.
    - A personal note from the Group General Counsel sent to the legal and secretariat function.
    - Reference and personal note from the CIO to his function.

- **”What you see and The real me” campaign:** Continues to highlight stories of colleagues from diverse backgrounds. Notably:
  - One of the Lighthouse co-chairs featured in seven initial stories, discussing acceptance and the strength of LGBTQ+ communities and networks within organisations.
  - This content has generated significant engagement with over 3,000 views on Viva Engage and 1,000+ views on the intranet homepage, accompanied by heartfelt comments.
  - The campaign promotes sharing, allyship, and acceptance by spotlighting diverse personal stories.

These approaches combine leadership endorsement, ongoing communication, storytelling, and community-building to foster greater comfort in self
column71: How does your organisation target and attract LGBTQ+ talent?
column72: We purposefully design our recruitment marketing to be as inclusive and diverse as possible. We publish LGBTQ+ specific content in support and celebration of Pride (example below), which is visible to over 177k followers on LinkedIn, many of whom a previous and prospective candidates and job applicants. Where we post video content, we aim to ensure that we have diverse representation from hiring teams to further cement our commitment to creating a place of work where the authentic self is valued and encouraged. All of our job adverts contain an inclusivity statement with further links into our D,E,I commitments: Our Inclusive Culture We are committed to exploring the possibilities of working smarter. This means we’d like to hear from you, whatever way you like to work. We have a long-term commitment to building inclusive workplaces; we value diversity in our workforce and welcome enquiries from everyone. If you need assistance or a reasonable adjustment due to a disability please let us know as part of your application and we will assist. You can find out more about our inclusive culture here. In addition, as part of our onboarding, candidates receive information about all of our employee networks, including our LGBTQ+ network, Lighthouse.
column73: It is encouraging to see the range of initiatives Abrdn uses to attract LGBTQ+ talent, however LGBTQ+ specificity can be enhanced through targeted LGBTQ+ outreach efforts, such as engaging with LGBT Great Careers as a part of your membership. column74:
Your organisation targets and attracts LGBTQ+ talent through a multi-faceted, inclusive approach:

- Recruitment marketing is intentionally designed to be diverse and inclusive.
- LGBTQ+ specific content is published in support and celebration of Pride, reaching over 177,000 LinkedIn followers, many of whom are past or prospective candidates.
- Video content features diverse representation from hiring teams to demonstrate a workplace culture that values authenticity.

This comprehensive strategy helps create a supportive and welcoming environment aimed at attracting and retaining LGBTQ+ talent.

column6: Executive Committee: Our LGBTQ+ Employee Network is supported by an ExCo sponsor dedicated to advocating for the network's initiatives and LGBTQ+ matters. This sponsor plays a pivotal role in securing support from the Executive Committee and senior management, helping to foster a company-wide culture of inclusivity. They act as a role model for being an ally and championing inclusive behaviours. They help to raise the profile of the employee networks and get buy in and support from the rest of the executive committee as needed. Non-Executive Management The driving forces from within this stakeholder group are the I&D committee, co-chaired by Ben Bramhall, our co-CEO, and Charlotte West, Head of Employee Engagement. This committee is tasked with shaping our overarching I&D strategy and overseeing its implementation. Formed of representatives from across our business functions and the network chairs, the committee draws on a wide range of perspectives to manage a comprehensive I&D programme. This programme addresses inclusion related to gender, ethnicity, disability and LGBTQ+ communities, alongside mental health and wellbeing. The I&D committee holds our employee networks accountable for achieving their strategic objectives and bi-annually reports their progress to the plc Board. Human Resources + D&I HR is responsible for facilitating the implementation of key initiatives, particularly around policies and process. Working in tandem with the networks, HR reviews these annually to ensure continuous improvement in fostering a fully inclusive environment. As part of our organisational structure, the D&I function falls within scope of the Employee Engagement Team which reports up to the HR Director. The team supports the employee networks, lends expertise on maximising the effectiveness of resource groups, orchestrates events and educational activities, and facilitates cross-functional collaboration for business-wide change. They set the standard for inclusive behaviour and work to maintain the visibility and buy-in of our DEI agenda through consistent communication and internal networking. Collaboration between HR and the Employee Engagement team is also key in delivering inclusion training to all line managers and new colleagues. Network Chairs The chairs of our Employee Networks (employee resource groups) are responsible for working with the wider network and business to establish a strategy for the year which identifies: • Priorities - key focus areas for the year • Objectives • Actions to achieve the defined objectives • Appropriate KPIs With the support of the EE Team, the Network chairs ensure the strategy is delivered across the year. There are also role models for inclusive behaviours and act as champions for all DE&I activity taking place across the business.
column8:
Certainly! Here's a summary of the responsibilities for LGBTQ+ DE&I within your organisation based on each stakeholder group mentioned:

1. **Executive Committee:**  
   - Sponsors and advocates for the LGBTQ+ Employee Network and its initiatives.  
   - Secures support from the Executive Committee and senior management to promote an inclusive culture.  
   - Acts as an ally and role model for inclusive behaviours.  
   - Raises the profile of employee networks and gains executive buy-in.

2. **Non-Executive Management (I&D Committee):**  
   - Shapes and oversees the overarching Inclusion & Diversity (I&D) strategy.  
   - Includes representatives from various business functions and network chairs to ensure diverse perspectives.  
   - Manages a comprehensive I&D programme covering gender, ethnicity, disability, LGBTQ+ communities, mental health, and wellbeing.  
   - Holds employee networks accountable for their strategic objectives.  
   - Reports progress bi-annually to the plc Board.

3. **Human Resources + Diversity & Inclusion (D&I):**  
   - Facilitates implementation of key policies and processes related to inclusion.  
   - Reviews policies annually to ensure continuous improvement of inclusivity.  
   - Supports employee networks with expertise and resources.  
   - Organises events, educational activities, and cross-functional collaboration initiatives.  
   - Sets standards for inclusive behaviour and maintains visibility of DE&I efforts through communication.  
   - Delivers inclusion training to line managers and new hires in coordination with the Employee Engagement Team
column11: For each of the selected stakeholder groups in Q3, please describe who they are and how they are measured against LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objectives. Please confirm that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column12: All Employees We have 5 organisational objectives that all employees are expected to demonstrate they are meeting through the year. There is a specific objective on Inclusion and Diversity which aims to create a holistically inclusive environment rather than targeting any group or category. The objective is worded as follows: “Everyone has the responsibility of making XPS a great place to work. We all have responsibility for actively promoting equality of opportunity, acting in line with our values and providing colleagues with the opportunity to share their ideas, views, and concerns.” The Employee Engagement Team Each network has a dedicated Employee Engagement Team lead. The Employee Engagement Team member then has specific objectives aligned to the delivery of key actions relating to the delivery of the network strategies they are linked to. Employee Resource Groups The employee resource groups are assessed annually by the I&D committee on what they have delivered over the year. With published strategies, action plans and KPIs for the year, these are used to track their impact. Performance by the networks then influence the budgets available to them in future years. Network chairs and members may also have individual objectives aligned to their contributions to these networks that they have agreed with their line managers. There is currently no expectation that this is done and so is down to individuals. Executive Committee While the Executive team don’t have specific LGBTQ+ Goals, they are held to account for the progress of our overall I&D strategy with their pay linked to this.
column14:
Here is a summary of the selected stakeholder groups, who they are, and how they are measured against LGBTQ+ DE&I goals and objectives based on your response:

1. **All Employees**  
   - **Who they are:** All staff members across the organization.  
   - **Measurement:** All employees are assessed annually against five organizational objectives, one of which focuses on Inclusion and Diversity. This objective emphasizes creating a holistically inclusive environment for everyone (not targeting specific groups). It involves promoting equality of opportunity, embodying company values, and fostering open communication of ideas, views, and concerns.

2. **Employee Engagement Team**  
   - **Who they are:** Members leading various employee networks related to DE&I efforts.  
   - **Measurement:** Each Employee Engagement Team lead has specific performance objectives tied to delivering key actions aligned with the respective network strategies they support.

3. **Employee Resource Groups (ERGs)**  
   - **Who they are:** Groups formed by employees to support diverse communities, including LGBTQ+ colleagues.  
   - **Measurement:** The I&D committee annually assesses ERGs based on their published strategies, action plans, and KPIs for the year to track impact. Their performance influences funding and budget allocations for future initiatives. Network chairs and members may also have individual objectives linked to their network contributions, though this is currently optional and dependent on agreements with line managers.

4. **Executive Committee**  
   - **Who they are:** The organization’s senior leadership team.
column17: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column18: Performance against organisational objectives and objectives relating to LGBTQ+ DE&I will impact an individual’s performance rating and therefore their bonus potential in the year. We also hold an annual employee award to recognise those that go above and beyond in demonstrating our values and championing inclusivity. Our nominees are all recognised for their contributions to XPS by a Teams call by one of the ExCo, while winners are recognised publicly across the business for their efforts, along with receiving a monetary award and trophy. See supporting evidence iiBT 01 for a screenshot of the intranet page announcing winners. Recognising the importance of role models, we celebrate the people who champion inclusion at XPS by sharing their employee stories internally and on social media. Network efforts are called out and acknowledged by the co-CEOs in their weekly voice notes to the whole business when they launch any new initiative or host an event (see supporting evidence iiBT 02). The employees who contributed in particular to specific initiatives and events also receive a thank you by the ExCo sponsor
column20:
Your organisation recognises and rewards employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I through several structured and visible initiatives:

1. **Performance Evaluation and Bonuses:** Employees' performance against organisational objectives, including specific objectives related to LGBTQ+ DE&I, influences their overall performance ratings and bonus potential.

2. **Annual Employee Awards:** An annual awards program highlights employees who excel in embodying company values and inclusivity. Nominees are recognized via a Teams call by an Executive Committee (ExCo) member, while winners receive public acknowledgment across the business, a monetary award, and a trophy. Supporting evidence includes an intranet announcement screenshot (iiBT 01).

3. **Celebration of Role Models:** The organisation shares stories of employees championing inclusion both internally and on social media to highlight role models for others.

4. **Leadership Acknowledgement:** Network efforts and contributions are acknowledged by the co-CEOs in their weekly voice notes to the entire company, especially when launching new initiatives or hosting events (iiBT 02).

5. **Executive Thank You:** Employees who make significant contributions to specific initiatives or events receive personal thanks from the ExCo sponsor.

These steps demonstrate a comprehensive approach to recognising and rewarding contributions to LGBTQ+ DE&I within your organisation.
column23: For each of the selected responses in Q7, please describe what proactive actions have been taken in the last 12 months by individuals and the organisation.
column24: In the last 12 months, we’ve delivered a number of actions aimed at building leadership and management understanding and awareness of LGBTQ+ issues. Key events have included: • Launching our three-part training series in collaborating with LGBT Great on Inclusive Language, Privilege and Allyship. • Hosting Freddy McConnell as a guest speaker to share his experiences of being transgender in the workplace, and the importance of inclusive practices and policies, drawing in particular from his experiences of being pregnant. • Providing line manager training on inclusion • Using the line manager Teams channel to share information and context around the launch of our Trans, Non-binary and Intersex inclusion policy and open up options for questions • Promoting LGBT Great Events internally and encouraging people to attend if possible • Including regular communications in the XPS Weekly News Update containing awareness information about key LGTBQ+ issues or topics (e.g. the importance of non-binary people’s day)
column26:
In the last 12 months, both individuals and the organisation have taken several proactive actions to enhance leadership and management understanding of LGBTQ+ issues:

- Launched a three-part training series in collaboration with LGBT Great, focusing on Inclusive Language, Privilege, and Allyship.
- Hosted Freddy McConnell as a guest speaker to share his experiences as a transgender individual in the workplace, emphasizing the significance of inclusive practices and policies, particularly relating to his pregnancy experiences.
- Provided inclusion-focused training specifically for line managers.
- Utilised the line manager Teams channel to disseminate information about the launch of the Trans, Non-binary, and Intersex inclusion policy, while also enabling open discussion and questions.
- Promoted LGBT Great Events internally and encouraged attendance to increase awareness.
- Included regular communications in the XPS Weekly News Update featuring awareness information on key LGBTQ+ issues and observances, such as the importance of Non-binary People’s Day.
column35: For each of the selected options in Q3, please describe how your LGBTQ+ DE&I strategy addresses each option.
column36: We focus on LGBTQ+ Talent retention and attraction through: • Building a community and safe space for LGBTQ+ employees to connect with each other • Collaborating with HR to develop inclusive policies and working practices • Educating the business on key LGBTQ+ issues so that we can ensure we have an inclusive environment • Promoting visible allyship with the use of pronouns and rainbow lanyards • Showcasing our commitment to inclusion on our social media channels and website We focus on Learning and Development for LGBTQ+ by offering both an internal mentoring scheme and the option to take part in the LGBT Great’s mentoring programme. Our internal mentoring scheme is open to all colleagues and not specific to LGBTQ+ colleagues, however mentors and mentees can request to be matched with another LGBTQ+ colleague. Our other L&D initiatives are available to all colleagues and include soft skills training delivered in-house, technical training opportunities, and both soft and technical online training courses. We are starting to look at how we can capture better LGBTQ+ Data and ROI information on relevant initiatives and events. We are currently looking at engagement with LGBTQ+ content vs. other DE&I content vs. general updates, getting feedback on all internal events, and encouraging employees to share their personal information on our HR system so we can track representation across our business areas and job grades. On communication, our strategy focuses on ensuring that language is inclusive and that we increase the visibility of the LGBTQ+ Network and relevant topics.
column39: If yes, please provide details of the process and which stakeholder is accountable for it? Please ensure that you have the permission of the person referenced to use their name.
column40: We conduct an annual review of the network strategy, looking at the feedback that has been received through our engagement surveys and network to identify key areas of focus. The KPIs set for the year (and outlined in the LGBTQ+ strategy deck) are checked periodically so that we can ensure to promote activities and initiatives that will help us meet those targets. Regular updates are provided to the I&D committee and wider network on progress. During general network discussions, we encourage regular feedback and input into our events and initiatives to ensure that we are doing things that work for our employees.

column45: For each of the selected options in Q6, please list the policy and provide supporting commentary. Please attach a copy of the policies.
column46: We don’t have a specific policy with each of the titles above, however we have a few separate polices which aim to cover the same topics: I&D Policy (iiBT 04) + Bullying and Harassment Prevention policy (iiBT 05) These policies set out expected behaviours for treating all employees with dignity and respect. It also ensures that everyone is explicitly aware that discrimination of any sort is not tolerated. The policies also outline the steps to report non-inclusive behaviour. Transgender, non-binary and intersex inclusion policy (iiBT 06) This policy covers transitioning at work and support that any of our transgender, non-binary and intersex colleagues may need. We also reference our Menopause policy and Health and Menopause network to support from a hormonal changes perspective. Family Friendly Leave Policy (iiBT 07) To make things easier for colleagues to find, and recognising different family units, we cover all family leave polices in one document which includes: • Share parental leave • Adoption • Maternity • Paternity Gender Expression (iiBT 21) We don't currently have a specific policy on gender expression, however we do have a guide about the value of sharing pronouns, and cover elements about gender expression in our transgender, non-binary and intersex inclusion policy. All our policies are independently reviewed either by our partner organisations (e.g. LGBT Great for LGBTQ+ related policies, or by the Inclusive Group - our external DEI consultants.
column48:
Certainly! Here is a summary of the policies corresponding to the selected options in Q6, along with supporting commentary:

1. **Inclusion & Diversity (I&D) Policy (iiBT 04) + Bullying and Harassment Prevention Policy (iiBT 05)**  
   - These policies collectively set expectations for treating all employees with dignity and respect.  
   - They explicitly prohibit any form of discrimination.  
   - Outline clear steps to report non-inclusive or inappropriate behavior in the workplace.

2. **Transgender, Non-Binary and Intersex Inclusion Policy (iiBT 06)**  
   - Focuses on supporting colleagues who are transgender, non-binary, or intersex, particularly in relation to transitioning at work.  
   - References additional resources such as the Menopause Policy and the Health and Menopause network to cover hormonal and related health considerations.

3. **Family Friendly Leave Policy (iiBT 07)**  
   - Combines all family leave policies into a single document for ease of access and reflects recognition of varied family structures.  
   - Covers share parental leave, adoption leave, maternity leave, and paternity leave.

4. **Gender Expression (iiBT 21)**  
   - While there is no stand-alone policy on gender expression, guidance exists regarding the importance of sharing pronouns.  
   - Elements of gender expression are included within the Transgender, Non-Binary and Intersex Inclusion Policy.

**Policy Review and Validation:**  
- All policies

column61: How does your organisation utilise sexual orientation and gender identity diversity data to improve LGBTQ+ DE&I?

column65: What campaigns, strategies or approaches has your organisation undertaken to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data?
column66: Have run a couple of count me in campaigns encouraging employees to share their sensitive information over the last few months to explain the business case for it collecting DE&I Data. We also specifically call out where the data is not used (e.g. in making decisions about an individual person, as part of performance appraisals etc.) Attached is one example of the promo materials we’ve used to encourage employees to share their data (iiBT 08 - Diversity Data Poster)

- Running "count me in" campaigns aimed at encouraging employees to share sensitive information.

column85: For each of the selected responses in Q6, what action was taken, and what outcomes were achieved over the last 12 months?
column86: Our attraction focus over the last 12 months has been focused on achieving our targets surrounding gender and ethnicity. So we haven’t taken actions focused specifically on LGBTQ+ talent attraction within the last 12 months. We explored the possibility of advertising key roles on the LGBT great career platform which would have been a great opportunity, however our legal team were not comfortable with a few of the terms that couldn’t be changed, and so we decided not to proceed with that option at this stage. While we haven’t targeted LGBTQ+ attraction specifically, we have taken various measures to showcase our approach to inclusion at XPS and our commitment to welcoming and encouraging people of all backgrounds. We’ve done so by sharing social media posts in recognition of key LGBTQ+ days, promoting the launch of our Trans, Non-binary and Intersex Inclusion policy, and employee stories. We also have an employee referral programme where employees are paid up to £2,500 for recommending a successful candidate in a role. The employee making the recommendation receives a first £1,000 payment when the new employee joins, and a second £1,500 payment once the new employee successfully completes probation.
column89: Please describe and attach examples of the content covered by this training.
column90: We provide mandatory DE&I training to all new joiners and specific workshops on 'inclusive leadership' to all line managers. This focuses on respectful behaviours and understanding unconscious bias, learning to mitigate the negative effects of how we judge each other and how to promote and encourage inclusive behaviour. This training is delivered by an external provider. In addition, we host voluntary training webinars specific to LGBTQ+ inclusion throughout the year. This may come in the form of specific training, guest speakers or panel discussions. More details on these are covered in response to question 2.

column110: Our LGBTQ+ Network has a communication plan to promote visibility of the network and raise awareness and understanding of LGBTQ+ topics and issues. (iiBT 17) These comms include: • Regular content shared on our intranet and through our weekly news updates. These generally focus on awareness days, communicating our initiatives and explaining the context around them. • Inclusion of LGBTQ+ topics in the weekly CEO voice notes sent to the organisation (iiBT 02) • Updates through a general I&D Network newsletter shared bi-annually (iiBT 18 - screenshot of the LGBTQ+ section of the newsletter) • Promotion of LGBTQ+ related events and activities through social media (iiBT 10 - example LinkedIn post) The network also helps provide feedback on other company communications to help ensure they are inclusive.
column113: If yes, please describe the process.
column114: Policy Process Existing policies are reviewed annually by HR. This review process includes consulting with key stakeholders across the business, including the diversity networks to ensure that our policies are inclusive and meet the needs of our employees. Over the last 12 months, recommendations made from a LGBTQ+ perspective have included: • Updating the wording in our dress code policy to be more explicit about enabling people to dress in a way which aligns with their gender identity regardless of biological sex, or the way they may present. • Including a clause in our absence policy to ensure that gender affirming care does not count towards short-term absence triggers • Reviewing the menopause policy which also covers significant hormone change and made recommendations for how this can be more inclusive towards anyone receiving hormone treatment or going through changes (and not just those experiencing menopause symptoms) For new policies, such as for our newly launched Transgender, Non-Binary, and Intersex Inclusion policy, we go through several rounds of drafting and gathering feedback from key stakeholders to ensure the content and language is inclusive. Stakeholders include: • Policy users • Line managers • Subject matter experts (from both relevant internal teams such as HR, IT and Compliance, and external partners) Internal Communications Our internal comms go through a review and sign-off process before being sent out to colleagues so that we can check to ensure language is inclusive throughout. Where comms are particularly sensitive, we consult with key stakeholders to ensure that we do the right thing for our employees, in line with our values and approach to DE&I.

column71: How does your organisation target and attract LGBTQ+ talent?
column72: our organisation target and attract LGBTQ+ talent?
column74:
To effectively target and attract LGBTQ+ talent, organizations can implement several strategies:

1. **Inclusive Employer Branding:** Highlight your commitment to diversity and inclusion in all recruitment materials, including your website, job postings, and social media channels. Use inclusive language and imagery that represent LGBTQ+ individuals.

2. **Partnerships with LGBTQ+ Organizations:** Collaborate with LGBTQ+ professional networks, community groups, and job boards to reach potential candidates.

3. **Employee Resource Groups (ERGs):** Establish and promote LGBTQ+ employee resource groups that can support recruitment efforts and provide a welcoming environment.

4. **Training and Awareness:** Provide unconscious bias and inclusivity training for hiring managers and recruiters to ensure a respectful and fair hiring process.

5. **Inclusive Policies and Benefits:** Offer policies that support LGBTQ+ employees, such as anti-discrimination policies, same-sex partner benefits, and support for gender transition.

6. **Attend LGBTQ+ Career Fairs and Events:** Participate in events that focus on LGBTQ+ professionals to increase visibility and engagement.

If you'd like, I can help you tailor these suggestions to your organization's specific context.

column12: Managers across the business are encouraged to carry out informal reviews regularly throughout the year and all staff, including our Executive Committee have a formal annual appraisal for the purpose of reviewing performance over the previous year and setting goals and targets for the year ahead. There is an emphasis on the ‘how’ objectives were achieved as well as the ‘what’, requiring appraiser and appraisee to comment on how the Artemis cultural principles have been demonstrated through their behaviours. The annual appraisal is also used as an opportunity to assess individual fitness and propriety for Senior Managers and Certified staff. However, as above, the Executive Committee do not have specific objectives related to individual strands and therefore there is not a LGBT+ specific objective, nor are there LGBT+ specific objectives within any other stakeholder groups. As our work in DEI matures, we know that the objectives and how they are measured, will have to evolve to match our progress
column13: As outlined, no LGBTQ+ specificity in goals and objectives as yet. An area of strategic focus for Artemis throughout the year ahead could be establishing measurable LGBTQ+ specific goals and objectives to further underpin growing LGBTQ+ DE&I maturity.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dWed, 02 Oct 2024 12:12:43 GMT|
column14:
The selected stakeholder groups include managers across the business and the Executive Committee. Managers are encouraged to conduct informal reviews regularly throughout the year, while all staff—including the Executive Committee—participate in a formal annual appraisal process. This appraisal reviews the individual's performance over the previous year and sets goals and targets for the upcoming year. Both appraiser and appraisee focus not only on the outcomes ('what' was achieved) but also on the manner in which objectives were met ('how'), with emphasis on demonstrating Artemis cultural principles through behaviour.

The annual appraisal additionally serves to assess fitness and propriety for Senior Managers and Certified staff. However, currently, the Executive Committee and other stakeholder groups do not have specific LGBTQ+ objectives integrated into their performance goals. As the organization's work in DEI (Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion) matures, these objectives and their measurement methods are expected to evolve to better reflect progress.

Regarding permission, the response does not reference any individual by name; therefore, no consent is required to use personal names.

column35: For each of the selected options in Q3, please describe how your LGBTQ+ DE&I strategy addresses each option.
column36: As before, we do not have an LGBT+ DEI strategy, however our wider work in DEI will support this indirectly. Examples of how our actions will address some of the above options: • Working with recruitment consultants and head-hunters who actively promote diverse candidates. Our interview process is more standardised, with increased HR involvement and challenge. • Taking a more coordinated approach to learning and development and leveraging specific programmes to support diverse talent. Examples include mentoring for female talent through the 30% club, targeted training for managers on policy and process, including recruitment (run by the HR team) and soft skills in conjunction with a specialist provided. • Supporting the pipeline of talent through active engagement with partners who specialise in working with young people in education (second and third level) to raise the profile of the investment management industry as an attractive career choice. We have built relationships with partners who work to raise the profile of the industry among underrepresented groups including girls and young people from socio economic groups that may not have been aware of the investment industry. These include Future Asset, Arrival Education, and Investment 20/20. We are also signing up to internship programmes through Girls Are Investors (GAIN) and 10,000 Black Interns As outlined in the above examples, we are hoping to increase the diverse talent available to us while also increasing knowledge internally that builds an inclusive culture where people of all backgrounds, orientations, gender, other beliefs, are supported and embraced.
column37: We are looking forward to seeing Artemis' centralised DE&I strategy evolve to specifically address the unique challenges and needs of LGBTQ+ employees by implementing some of the elements outlined in Q3 and as outlined above. column61: How does your organisation utilise sexual orientation and gender identity diversity data to improve LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column62: From our current point, working to encourage more staff to anonymously report on their sexual orientation through our staff survey is the first step to improving LGBT+ DEI at Artemis. An increase in those feeling comfortable to disclose this information anonymously has shown that safety in disclosure has improved. To note that through our current anonymity settings, five people must pick the same answer before it is reportable back to us. Therefore, depending on our demographic breakdown, we may never see a representative sample of staff who are LGBTQ+ through the anonymous survey reporting tool
column63: Comprehensive approach to data capture and analysis demonstrated with clear connections between data insights and specific actions taken which aim to improve LGBTQ+ DE&I in future.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dWed, 02 Oct 2024 13:07:17 GMT|
