column66: Before we started to collect the data, we explained to staff via emails and staff calls why we were doing so and how it would help. Also, whenever one of the workstreams has delivered an event or there is a DEI communication to staff, we have again encouraged them to disclose this data.
column67: Evidence of some specific actions taken to improve comfort around disclosure.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dWed, 02 Oct 2024 13:07:17 GMT|
column68: The organisation has undertaken a communication-focused approach to improve comfort around disclosing self-identification DE&I data. Specifically, before beginning data collection, staff were informed through emails and staff calls about the purpose of gathering this information and how it would be beneficial. Additionally, the organisation consistently encourages disclosure through DE&I communications and events delivered by various workstreams, reinforcing the importance and safety of sharing such data.
column71: How does your organisation target and attract LGBTQ+ talent?
column72: While we do not actively target LGBT+ talent, we have reviewed and refined our recruitment approach to ensure that we attract and approach a diverse range of candidates. We have committed to take active steps to hire, develop and retain a diverse workforce. Examples of some of the actions include: • Working with recruitment consultants and head-hunters who actively promote diverse candidates. Our interview process is more standardised, with increased HR involvement and challenge. • Supporting the pipeline of talent through active engagement with partners who specialise in working with young people in education (second and third level) to raise the profile of the investment management industry as an attractive career choice. We have built relationships with partners who work to raise the profile of the industry among underrepresented groups including girls and young people from socio economic groups that may not have been aware of the investment industry. These include Future Asset, Arrival Education, and Investment 20/20. We are also signing up to internship programmes through Girls Are Investors (GAIN) and 10,000 Black Interns. While these do not specifically target LGBT+ talent, we hope that by broadening the net we will see an increase of talent across all of the DEI strands. Earlier this year, during Pride month, we organised internal and external initiatives to raise awareness of LGBT+ issues. Our logo was changed for the whole month on our website. The video message posted on LinkedIn from our CIO was specifically related to pride month and we hope highlighted Artemis' commitment to DEI to potential future employees.
column73: It is great to learn about the range of DE&I initiatives that Artemis has implemented attract diverse talent, however there is little evidence of LGBTQ+ specificity provided here which limits maturity from an LGBTQ+ lens in this area. column74:
Your organisation's approach to targeting and attracting LGBTQ+ talent involves creating an inclusive and diverse recruitment strategy rather than specifically targeting LGBTQ+ individuals. Key elements include:

- Collaborating with recruitment consultants and head-hunters who promote diverse candidates.
- Standardising the interview process with greater HR oversight to ensure fairness.
- Engaging with educational partners (such as Future Asset, Arrival Education, and Investment 20/20) to attract underrepresented groups to the investment management industry.
- Participating in internship programmes like Girls Are Investors (GAIN) and 10,000 Black Interns to broaden the talent pipeline.
- During Pride month, implementing visibility initiatives such as updating the company logo and sharing messages from leadership on social media to raise awareness and demonstrate commitment to LGBTQ+ inclusion.

While LGBTQ+ talent is not specifically targeted, these broader diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts aim to foster an environment that attracts and supports talent across all diverse groups, including LGBTQ+ individuals.
column77: How does your organisation seek to position itself as an LGBTQ+ inclusive employer?
column78: The initiatives run during Pride 2022, positioning Artemis as an LGBT+ inclusive employer, were the first of their kind at the firm. Until that point, while we had outlined our commitment to DEI on the website (https://www.artemisfunds.com/en/about-artemis/diversity-and-inclusion) we had not run a campaign that related directly to Artemis being an LGBT+ inclusive employer before. In fact, this was the first campaign run like this relating to Artemis being an inclusive employer more generally. On an ongoing basis, our commitment to DEI is outlined on the firm website and the third parties we work with or are members of (including LGBT Great) are outlined under what we do as an employer, and our subsequent commitments.
column79: Evidence of messaging on LGBTQ+ inclusion, specific content namely the video featuring Paras Anand on the website and LGBTQ+ focussed employer branding. We are happy to discuss ways of improving the scale and scope of these initiatives with Artemis as part of your membership.-- LGBTGreat/Clara /dWed, 02 Oct 2024 14:21:46 GMT|

column17: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column18: Jupiter takes a broad approach to celebrating individuals who play a significant role in upholding our unique culture. This includes: Proud awards: a monetary award of £1000 given on a monthly basis to individuals who have gone above and beyond to support Jupiter’s culture. In 2023, Claire Mediene and David Bone (previous Chairs of the Pride Network) were nominated and won the award for their exceptional efforts in driving forward the actions of the Pride Network. CEO ‘Cultural Ambassadors’ event – run for the first time at the start of 2024, individuals including all Network Chairs and other individuals who have made a significant contribution to Jupiter’s culture were invited to a celebratory evening hosted by Matt Beesley to recognise their significant contributions. Mett Beesley, CEO, Chairs the DE&I Forum at Jupiter, giving him an opportunity to hear first hand about the work of the Networks, and give them enhanced visibility and recognition in the firm. All Networks have an allocated budget that they are empowered and trusted to spend on activities that promote the agenda of the Network. Whilst this is not individual recognistion, it recognised the importance of the Networks and their abilities in defining an annual plan.
column20:
Jupiter recognises and rewards employees supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I through several key initiatives:

- **Proud Awards:** A monthly monetary award of £1000 is given to individuals who have significantly contributed to Jupiter’s culture. For example, in 2023, Claire Mediene and David Bone, former Chairs of the Pride Network, received this award for their outstanding efforts in advancing the Pride Network's initiatives.

- **CEO ‘Cultural Ambassadors’ Event:** Initiated in early 2024, this event invites Network Chairs and other key individuals who have notably contributed to Jupiter’s culture to a celebratory evening hosted by CEO Matt Beesley, providing formal recognition of their efforts.

- **Leadership Engagement:** CEO Matt Beesley chairs Jupiter’s DE&I Forum, allowing him to stay directly informed about the Networks’ work and enhance visibility and recognition of their contributions across the firm.

- **Network Budgets:** Each Employee Network, including the Pride Network, has a dedicated budget they can use autonomously to plan and execute activities that promote their specific agendas, supporting ongoing cultural and DE&I engagement, though this serves as organisational rather than individual recognition.

Together, these approaches ensure that efforts supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I at Jupiter are acknowledged both formally and informally, fostering a culture of appreciation and empowerment.
column23: For each of the selected responses in Q7, please describe what proactive actions have been taken in the last 12 months by individuals and the organisation.
column24: We have run two training events in partnership with LGBT Great this year, one session delivered to all Network members on how to run an effective employee Network, and one on intersectionality. Our session on intersectionality included a panel of Jupiter employees, including Kiran Nandra, Head of Equities (ExCo member), and was attended by over 100 employees. In 2023, Claire Mediene also hosted a session on Allyship for Jupiter colleagues with Interinvest. Jupiter sponsored and hosted an Interinvest panel on bi-visibility in 2023, including external attendees in Jupiter’s offices and more recently promoted the event with Interinvest with the Charity ‘Just Like Us’. All LGBT Great and Interinvest events are open to Jupiter employees. Our new Jupiter intranet allows for better visibility for such events.

column62: We use the data to monitor demographic shifts at Jupiter. By collecting gender identity data, we demonstrate to employees that we are an inclusive employer. column65: What campaigns, strategies or approaches has your organisation undertaken to improve comfort around disclosing self-ID DE&I data?
column66: We have seen a 3-4% improvement in disclosure against both sexual orientation and gender identity. In 2023, we began collecting this data for the first time and undertook a communications campaign to encourage individuals to disclose at the time. We have not made specific efforts to increase this this year, but we are pleased to see an incremental increase in the rate of disclosure despite not pushing this topic. We believe that our broad and visible efforts on inclusion contribute to this shift.
column68:

column5: For each of the selected answers in Q1, please describe what responsibilities they have for LGBTQ+ DE&I in your organisation.
column6: All of our people are responsible for inclusion within the organisation. Our DEI strategy is ultimately the responsibility of our Board with LCP’s CEO as executive responsible for DEI outcomes. The strategy is overseen by a DEI Committee which includes LCP’s Head of People, Head of HR, our DEI manager, another senior partner, and a senior representative from each of our four DEI networks. There is no single area of responsibility as it is central to our entire culture and people principles. The LCP Board, with the support of the DEI Committee, regularly reviews our overall DEI strategy, long-term objectives, DEI purpose and vision and supports the Networks, including the LGBTQ+ Network, to articulate their long-term aims and objectives. To support this strategy, the DEI Committee sets overarching areas of focus and success criteria each year with input from the Networks and stakeholders across LCP and each of the four DEI Networks (LGBTQ+, Women’s, Wellbeing, Multicultural) also agree individual success criteria each year. Progress is regularly reviewed by the DEI Committee to reflect on progress over the year and agree next steps. The current overarching aims and long-term objectives for the LGBTQ+ network are below: • Provide a welcoming and inclusive environment for LCPers who identify as LGBTQ+ o Run a series of socials and events o Drive attendance at regular coffee mornings o Work with HR to understand whether LGBTQ+ colleagues are overrepresented in leavers from LCP • Have an influence outside our network by raising awareness, being visible, and supporting our wider community o Increase visibility by posting on Viva Engage o Use events and other means to raise money for our nominated charities, where relevant and appropriate to do so • Promote LCP externally as an LGBTQ+ inclusive employer, expanding and deepening LCP’s connections with clients, peers and industry groups. o Build on success of last year’s client event o Continue to support industry groups such as O:Pen, LINK, and TIDE o Build connections with LGBTQ+ individuals as clients and firms who refer us work. Examples of the success criteria against these objectives specific to this year include: • Running at least three socials / events, with at least one to have a trans awareness focus • Work with other networks to deliver intersectional events (eg book or film clubs, or a panel event) • Target average attendance at coffee mornings of 10+ people • A fundraising target of £1,500 for the year plus matching from the LCP Foundation • Target 120+ attendees with similarly positive feedback for an annual client event • Utilise LGBT Great training credit
column8:
The responsibilities for LGBTQ+ DE&I in your organisation are shared across multiple levels and groups, reflecting an integrated and comprehensive approach:

- **All Employees:** Everyone is responsible for fostering inclusion as part of the organisation’s culture and people principles.

- **Board of Directors:** Ultimately accountable for the overall DEI strategy and outcomes, the Board regularly reviews the DEI strategy, long-term objectives, and vision. They also support the DEI Networks, including the LGBTQ+ Network, in setting and articulating long-term aims.

- **CEO:** Holds executive responsibility for achieving DEI outcomes within the organisation.

- **DEI Committee:** Oversees the DEI strategy and its implementation. Its members include:
  - Head of People
  - Head of HR
  - DEI Manager
  - A senior partner
  - Senior representatives from each of the four DEI networks (LGBTQ+, Women’s, Wellbeing, Multicultural)

  This committee sets annual focus areas and success criteria with input from various stakeholders and networks, monitors progress throughout the year, and determines next steps.

- **LGBTQ+ Network:** Focuses on specific objectives including:
  - Providing an inclusive and welcoming environment for LGBTQ+ employees by organizing socials, coffee mornings, and working with HR on retention data.
  - Raising awareness and visibility both internally and externally, such as posting on Viva Engage and supporting charitable fundraising.
  - Promoting the organisation externally as an LGBTQ+ inclusive employer by hosting client events,

column17: How does your organisation recognise and reward employees for their efforts in supporting LGBTQ+ DE&I?
column18: Performance against objectives is measured at annual appraisals, and feeds into bonus and pay review consideration. There is a large degree of discretion to annual bonuses, and therefore significant efforts to supporting DEI causes can be rewarded. Time spent on LGBTQ+ inclusion activities, or on wider DEI leadership, is considering “productive time” when it comes to reviewing hours charged as part of year end appraisals. In addition our employee recognition awards include an award category focussed on those making an impact in the DEI and within the broader CSR space. Individuals are nominated by other colleagues for the work and effort they put in with those with significant achievements being fully recognised across the business for their contribution.
column20:
Your response effectively outlines how your organisation recognises and rewards employees supporting LGBTQ+ Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DE&I). You clearly explain that performance evaluations during annual appraisals contribute to bonus and pay review decisions, with discretion allowing meaningful efforts in DEI to be financially rewarded. Highlighting that time spent on LGBTQ+ inclusion or broader DEI leadership counts as productive work supports recognition of these contributions. Additionally, mentioning the employee recognition awards with a DEI focus and peer-nomination process emphasizes inclusive acknowledgement of impactful efforts.

To enhance clarity and flow, you might consider slight rephrasing. Here's a polished version of your response:

---

Performance against objectives is assessed during annual appraisals and informs bonus and pay review considerations. Given the discretionary nature of annual bonuses, significant efforts in supporting DEI initiatives, including LGBTQ+ inclusion, can be meaningfully rewarded. Furthermore, time dedicated to LGBTQ+ inclusion activities or wider DEI leadership is regarded as “productive time” when reviewing hours charged at year-end appraisals.

In addition, our employee recognition awards feature a category specifically focused on individuals making a notable impact in DEI and the broader Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) space. Colleagues nominate individuals based on their effort and contributions, with those demonstrating significant achievements receiving formal recognition across the business.

---

column71: How does your organisation target and attract LGBTQ+ talent?
column72: We publicise our diversity, equity and inclusion work and initiatives, emphasise how this fits in with our culture and also seek feedback from applicants on whether they have been drawn to us because of our efforts in this area. We run Life At LCP Instagram and Linked In accounts to be able to more freely share our less formal initiatives and practices. We are actively ensuring applicants are aware we are inclusive. Over the last year we have (and continue to) make use of the LGBT Great jobs board to advertise our vacancies. We are a member of the diversity project, LGBT Great, Link and are a founding member of O:Pen. This allows us to actively raise awareness and develop an LGBTQ+ employer brand. We have a number of openly LGBTQ+ senior colleagues, who are celebrated openly on our social media. We include DEI as a priority in all of our recruitment events, be that university fairs or careers fairs. Our networks feature heavily in new business pitches.

column77: How does your organisation seek to position itself as an LGBTQ+ inclusive employer?
column78: Through our policies, procedures, press releases, recruitment initiatives, our advocacy work, our support of LGBTQ+ charities, publicity in new business responses and presentations, highlighting our work at conferences and events, and inviting clients to our DEI Network events. We also work with our clients to improve their own DEI practices and governance. We host a large annual client event to celebrate Pride month and ensure that this is widely advertised to clients, mutual advisers within the industry, and to potential recruits. We advertise ourselves as an LGBTQ+ inclusive employer on our “Life at LCP” Instagram page, which we use to celebrate our various DEI initiatives and events. We also have a dedicated space on our recruitment website to show our commitment to DEI and the work that our networks do. We signpost our DEI commitment and provide briefing on our networks and initiatives to recruitment agencies so that they are able to speak to candidates about what we do in this area.

column68:
It sounds like you are seeking examples or suggestions on campaigns, strategies, or approaches to improve comfort around disclosing self-identified Diversity, Equity & Inclusion (DE&I) data, particularly related to LGBT+ identities.

Here are some potential approaches your organisation might consider:

1. **Confidentiality Assurance:** Clearly communicate how personal data is protected and used only in aggregate to help build trust.

2. **Leadership Advocacy:** Have leaders openly discuss and support DE&I initiatives, sharing their own stories if comfortable, to normalize self-ID.

3. **Inclusive Language and Environment:** Use inclusive language in communications and create safe spaces that affirm all identities.

4. **Voluntary and Anonymous Options:** Allow employees to disclose data voluntarily and offer anonymous feedback channels.

5. **Awareness Campaigns:** Run internal campaigns highlighting the importance of self-ID data for shaping inclusive policies and benefits.

6. **Training and Education:** Provide DE&I training to build understanding and reduce stigma around different identities.

7. **Visible ERGs:** Support Employee Resource Groups for LGBT+ employees to foster community and trust.

If you share more about your organisation’s current efforts or culture, I can tailor recommendations further.

Would you like me to help you draft feedback comments based on any of these points?
